-->                         <section id="main"> <article class="post-49 page type-page status-publish hentry">  <header>   <h1 class="title">Concealed Carry Permit Reciprocity Maps</h1> </header>  <section class="entry">      <ul id="sharebar" style="background:#;border-color:#;"> <li><iframe doNotCopy:true,hashAddressBar:false});</script><span class="st_facebook_hcount" displayText="Share"></span><span class="st_sharethis" displayText="Share"></span></li></ul><div class="pf-content"><p>The permit maps below will show you which states you can carry concealed in as well as which state&#8217;s permits are honored in a particular state. If you have a concealed carry permit and want to know which state you can carry in use the default map &#8220;States That Honor My Permit(s). If you want to know which state&#8217;s permits are honored in a particular state, click on the &#8220;Permits Honored By State&#8221; tab. If you need help with these maps or what reciprocity means, <a href="#concealed-carry-reciprocity">click here to view our detailed explanation below.</a></p> <link href="/permitmaps_v2/css/reset.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" /> <link href="/permitmaps_v2/css/styles.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" /><script language="javascript" type="text/javascript" type="text/javascript" src="/permitmaps_v2/js/easyTooltip.js"></script><script language="javascript" type="text/javascript" src="/permitmaps_v2/js/functions.js"></script></p> <div id="lightbox_mask"></div> <div id="permit_maps"> <div id="tabs_wrapper">   <a href="javascript:loadMap(1);" id="map_tab_1">States That Honor My Permit(s)</a><a href="javascript:loadMap(2);" id="map_tab_2">Permits Honored By State</a>     </div> <div id="map_description"></div> <div style="text-align:right;"><a href="javascript:doPrint();">Print</a></div> <div id="map_wrapper"> <div /> <area shape="poly" id="wy_1" class="none" title="Wyoming" href="javascript:void(0);" coords="159,94,161,94,161,95,168,95,168,96,176,96,176,97,184,97,184,98,191,98,191,99,200,99,200,100,209,100,209,101,219,101,219,102,226,102,226,103,226,112,225,112,225,125,224,125,224,131,225,131,225,136,224,136,224,147,223,147,223,156,222,156,222,157,216,157,216,156,209,156,209,155,200,155,200,154,190,154,190,153,182,153,182,152,174,152,174,151,167,151,167,150,160,150,160,149,153,149,153,148,152,148,152,142,153,142,153,136,154,136,154,129,155,129,155,123,156,123,156,117,157,117,157,112,158,112,158,105,159,105,159,95" /> <area shape="rect" id="vi_1" title="Virgin Islands" class="{fillOpacity:'0'}" coords="560,323,589,342" href="javascript:void(0);" /> <area shape="rect" id="pr_1" title="Puerto Rico" class="{fillOpacity:'0'}" coords="562,349,593,368" href="javascript:void(0);" /> <area shape="rect" id="nmi_1" title="N. Mariana Islands" class="{fillOpacity:'0'}" coords="562,375,599,394" href="javascript:void(0);" /> <area shape="rect" id="as_1" title="American Samoa" class="{fillOpacity:'0'}" coords="561,401,593,420" href="javascript:void(0);" /> <area shape="rect" id="gu_1" title="Guam" class="{fillOpacity:'0'}" coords="562,427,594,447" href="javascript:void(0);" /> </map> <div class="woo-sc-box note   "><strong>NOTES:</strong></div> <ul> <li>Wisconsin accepts Nevada ISSUED OR RENEWED ON OR AFTER 07/01/2011.</li> <li>Wisconsin accepts Virginia Non-Resident Permits Only.</li> <li>Wisconsin accepts West Virginia license ISSUED OR RENEWED AFTER 06/08/12.</li> <li>Wisconsin accepts Alaska license ISSUED OR RENEWED ON OR AFTER 1/14/2013.</li> <li>Wisconsin accepts Missouri license ISSUED OR RENEWED ON OR AFTER 08/28/2013. This DOES NOT include any provisional license issued by the state.</li> <li>For a non-resident, South Carolina is not a shall-issue state, since they require property ownership for non-residents.</li> </ul> <div class="woo-sc-box info   "><strong>Recent Changes:</strong><br /> 9.8/2014 &#8211; Nevada and Louisiana no longer have reciprocity. [<a href="http://www.nvrepository.state.nv.us/ccw_changes.shtml" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 8/4/2014 &#8211; Montana honors Illinois Permits. [<a href="https://doj.mt.gov/enforcement/concealed-weapons/" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 7/31/2014 &#8211; Nevada honors Illinois Permits. [<a href="http://www.nvrepository.state.nv.us/ccw_changes.shtml" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 7/14/2014 &#8211; Pennsylvania and Utah now have reciprocity. [<a href="http://www.attorneygeneral.gov/uploadedFiles/Crime/Utah_reciprocity_agreement.pdf" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 6/22/2014 &#8211; Nebraska honors Illinois Permits. [<a href="https://statepatrol.nebraska.gov/media/10076/ccwagltrrecognitioofillinoispermits.pdf" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 5/27/2014 &#8211; Virginia and Washington now honor Kansas permits. [a href=&#8221;http://www.ag.ks.gov/public-safety/concealedcarry/out-of-state-license-recognition&#8221; target=&#8221;_blank&#8221;&gt;source</a>]<br /> 5/23/2014 &#8211; Wisconsin honors Nevada ISSUED OR RENEWED ON OR AFTER 07/01/2011. [<a href="http://www.doj.state.wi.us/dles/cib/conceal-carry/reciprocity" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 4/7/2014 &#8211; Wisconsin honors Illinois. [<a href="http://www.doj.state.wi.us/dles/cib/conceal-carry/reciprocity" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 3/19/2014 &#8211; Alaska honors Illinois. [<a href="http://dps.alaska.gov/statewide/PermitsLicensing/reciprocity.aspx" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 3/5/2014 &#8211; New Mexico honors Wyoming. [<a href="http://www.dps.nm.org/index.php/nm-concealed-carry/reciprocity-agreeements/" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 1/16/2014 &#8211; Ohio accepts Arizona Non-Resident. [<a href="http://www.ohioattorneygeneral.gov/Files/Publications/Publications-for-Law-Enforcement/Concealed-Carry-Publications/Concealed-Carry-Reciprocity-Agreements/Arizona-Concealed-Carry-Reciprocity-Agreement.aspx" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 1/12/2014 &#8211; Delaware no longer honors Virginia. [<a href="http://attorneygeneral.delaware.gov/crime/concealedweapons.shtml" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 10/31/2013 &#8211; Updated to reflect West Virginia signing reciprocity agreements with Iowa and New Hampshire [<a href="http://www.wvago.gov/gunrecep.cfm" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 9/16/2013 &#8211; Updated to reflect Ohio only accepting Arizona Resident Permits Only [<a href="http://www.ohioattorneygeneral.gov/Files/Publications/Publications-for-Law-Enforcement/Concealed-Carry-Publications/Concealed-Carry-Reciprocity-Agreements/Arizona-Concealed-Carry-Reciprocity-Agreement.aspx" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 9/3/2013 &#8211; Colorado and West Virginia have full reciprocity. [<a href="http://www.wvago.gov/gunrecep.cfm" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 8/26/2013 &#8211; Pennsylvania updated to show they only accept Maine Resident Permits [<a href="http://www.attorneygeneral.gov/uploadedFiles/Crime/Maine-PA-Reciprocity-Agreement.pdf" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 8/21/2013 &#8211; Georgia and West Virginia now have reciprocity. [<a href="http://www.wvago.gov/gunrecep.cfm" target="_blank">WV source</a> &#8211; <a href="http://law.ga.gov/firearm-permit-reciprocity" target="_blank">GA source</a>]<br /> 8/6/2013 &#8211; Wyoming now honors Kansas. [<a href="http://ag.ks.gov/media-center/news-releases/2013/08/02/ag-schmidt-kansas-concealed-carry-licenses-now-recognized-in-wyoming" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 8/1/2013 &#8211; Alabama accepts all other state&#8217;s permits.<br /> 7/29/2013 &#8211; Pennsylvania accepts Kansas Permits. [<a href="http://www.attorneygeneral.gov/crime.aspx?id=184" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 7/29/2013 &#8211; Pennsylvania will no longer accept Idaho carry permits [<a href="http://www.attorneygeneral.gov/crime.aspx?id=184" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 7/23/2013 &#8211; Alabama changed to Shall Issue<br /> 7/9/2013 &#8211; Illinois Concealed Carry Law Enacted [<a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2013/07/09/illinois-enacts-concealed-gun-law/2503083/" target="_blank">source</a>]<br /> 7/7/2013 &#8211; Kansas now accepts all state&#8217;s permits. [<a href="http://ag.ks.gov/public-safety/concealedcarry/out-of-state-license-recognition" target="_blank">source</a>]</div> <p><b>Difference Between Concealed Carry Recognition and Reciprocity</b><a name="concealed-carry-reciprocity"></a>Some states have reciprocity agreements with other states which means each state honors the other state&#8217;s concealed carry permit. </p> <p>Example of <strong>concealed carry reciprocity</strong> between two states: State A accepts State B&#8217;s <strong>concealed carry permit</strong> holders to carry in State A and State B accepts State A&#8217;s <strong>concealed carry permit</strong>holders to carry in State B.</p> <p>There are also some cases where State A will accept State C&#8217;s <strong>concealed carry permit</strong> holders but State C WILL NOT accept State A&#8217;s <strong>concealed carry permit holders</strong>. This is NOT <strong>reciprocity</strong>.</p> <p>The <strong>Concealed Carry Reciprocity Maps</strong> above will show you:</p> <p><strong>Map 1 &#8211; States That Honor My Permit(s):</strong><br /> The first screen on this map shows whether a state is <strong>Shall Issue</strong>, <strong>May Issue</strong>, or <strong>Right Denied</strong>.</p> <p><strong>Shall Issue</strong>: States that are <strong>Shall Issue</strong> will issue any private citizen a <strong>concealed weapons permit</strong> as long as they meet all requirements.</p> <p><strong>May Issue</strong>: States that are <strong>May Issue</strong> have the authority to take judgment on whether or not they want to issue a <strong>concealed weapons permit</strong> to a private citizen even after they have met all requirements.</p> <p><strong>Right Denied</strong>: States that are <strong>Right Denied</strong> DO NOT allows private citizens to carry handguns and do not issue <strong>concealed weapon permits</strong>.</p> <p>To view which states accept your <strong>concealed weapons permit</strong>, just click on the state your permit is issued in. If you have multiple permits, start with your <strong>Resident Permit</strong> (The permit issued in the state you live in).</p> <p>You may be asked if your <strong>concealed weapons permit</strong> is a Resident or Non-Resident permit. Some states issue permits to Residents of their state as well as Non-Residents. On the other hand, some state&#8217;s ONLY issue to Residents of their state. And to take it one step further, some states only allow permits issued to Residents of the states they have <strong>reciprocity</strong> with. This is what the yellow state color means on the map.</p> <p>If you need to reset the map and start over just click on the Clear Map button.</p> <p><strong>Map 2 &#8211; Permits Honored by State</strong><br /> This map is a quick way to find out what state <strong>concealed carry permits</strong> a particular state allows. Just click on a state and any states that are blue are allowed within the selected state, red are not allowed, and yellow means only residents of that state that have permits are allowed. </td> <td valign="top"></td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>Check out <a href="http://onthevise.com" target="_blank" title="On The Vise">On The Vise</a>, the new <a href="http://onthevise.com" title="Fly Tying">Fly Tying</a> site by the creator of USA Carry.</p> <div class="printfriendly pf-alignright"><a href="http://www.printfriendly.com/print?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.usacarry.com%2Fconcealed_carry_permit_reciprocity_maps.html" rel="nofollow" onclick="window.print(); return false;"><img style="border:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none; box-shadow:none;" src="http://cdn.printfriendly.com/pf-button.gif" alt="Print Friendly" /></a></div></div> </section><!-- /.entry -->  <div class="fix"></div> </article><!-- /.post --> <div id="disqus_thread">             <div id="dsq-content">             <ul id="dsq-comments">                     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-24">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-24" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-24">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-24">Sscsmi</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-24" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-24" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>This map is incorrect; the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations is a MAY ISSUE.  I had issues when I lived there getting my permit adn I was a licensed Private Detective.  The AG&#8217;s office denied me with the excuse that they felt they had already issued to many permits.  However state laws shows that the AG&#8217;s office is MAY ISSUE but it also shows that the Chief of Police for the City or Town you reside or work in SHALL ISSUE you a permit if you met the criteria established by law; however, they often refuse to do say claiming they dont have the authoirty until you file suit against both that city adn the chief of police specifically then they will follow the law and issue the permit.  This is what I had to do to obtain my permit there as a Licensed Private Detective working as a Bail enforcement Agent chasing wanted persons.  Although you do not need a ccw to carry a long gun in public or your vehicle as it is not concealabe!</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-34">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-34" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-34"> http://twitter.com/USACarry                <span id="dsq-author-user-34">USA Carry</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-34" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-34" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>We have no way of showing a status like this on the map but our new version will. Interstate transportation of firearms</p> <p>Notwithstanding any other provision of any law or any rule or regulation of a State or any political subdivision thereof, any person who is not otherwise prohibited by this chapter from transporting, shipping, or receiving a firearm shall be entitled to transport a firearm for any lawful purpose from any place where he may lawfully possess and carry such firearm to any other place where he may lawfully possess and carry such firearm if, during such transportation the firearm is unloaded, and neither the firearm nor any ammunition being transported is readily accessible or is directly accessible from the passenger compartment of such transporting vehicle: Provided, That in the case of a vehicle without a compartment separate from the driver’s compartment the firearm or ammunition shall be contained in a locked container other than the glove compartment or console.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-391">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-391" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-391">                 <span however the map shows otherwise.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-133">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-133" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-133">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-133">Anonymous</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-133" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-133" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>No, Nevada does not accept Utah permits.</p> <p><a href="http://nvrepository.state.nv.us/ccw_changes.shtml" rel="nofollow">http://nvrepository.state.nv.us/ccw_changes.shtml</a></p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-132">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-132" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-132"> http://pulse.yahoo.com/_56EIV5LCFB422A3SMXMPCGOW74                <span id="dsq-author-user-132">KSWildcat</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-132" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-132" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>My bust:  &#8220;Nevada Will No Longer Recognize Utah and Florida Right-to-Carry Permits (Thursday, June 25, 2009) . . . Effective, July 1, Nevada will no longer recognize Right-to-Carry permits from Utah or Florida.  They have, however, added Ohio and West Virginia as recognized states. . . Florida will no longer be recognized because its permits are now valid for seven years instead of five . . . &#8221;</p> <p>Effective, July 1, Nevada will no longer recognize Right-to-Carry permits from Utah or Florida.  They have, however, added Ohio and West Virginia as recognized states.  </p> <p>Each May, the Nevada Department of Public Safety conducts an audit of states and their Right-to-Carry laws for the purpose of determining which states it will recognize.  </p> <p>The Nevada DPS dropped Utah because it does not have a live fire requirement, which is a part of Nevada&#8217;s training requirements.  When the Nevada DPS first began its state by state audit of Right-to-Carry laws in 2007, DPS admitted to NRA representatives that they overlooked the live fire training requirement.  After further review, they determined that Utah wasn&#8217;t similar enough to keep it on the list of recognized states.  </p> <p>Florida will no longer be recognized because its permits are now valid for seven years instead of five.</p> <p>The Nevada DPS and the Nevada Sheriffs and Chiefs will be hosting their annual Right-to-Carry forum in Carson City in August with a teleconference feed to Las Vegas.  We encourage all members to attend this informational meeting.  Details will be forthcoming.  </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-166">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-166" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-166">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-166">Gryryder</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-166" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-166" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>It is about time, that the policy of Utah&#8217;s requirements for CCW has surfaced. I for one fail to see where a 3 hour, in classroom BS session, would qualify an individual to receive any degree of a  CCW permit. It is all about the money and nothing else. For the privilege to obtain a Utah CCW an applicant must pay a Utah excepted instructor $XXX.00 and then pay a second fee for the Utah CCW.</p> <p>Also, hold on to yopur wallets. Pennsylvania has and/or is revising their standards of CCW permit requirement. It appears that some politician has discovered, that the state is not receiving their fair share of the CCW application proceeds and have enacted legislationas to a &#8220;MUST APPEAR REQUIREMENT&#8221; to process the applicant&#8217;s application.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-138">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-138" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-138">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-138">Ds7</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-138" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-138" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I do believe that Noth Carolina has Iowa listed as a state they recognize now.  It is posted on there web site.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-140">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-140" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-140">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-140">Anonymous</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-140" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-140" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Thanks, this has been updated.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-159">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-159" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-159">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-159">Laurence</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-159" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-159" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Have none of the lawmakers of the various states ever read the U. S. Constitution, which they are allegedly sworn to uphold?  Article IV of the Constitution states quite clearly:</p> <p>Full Faith and Credit shall be given in each State to the public Acts, Records, and judicial Proceedings of every other State. And the Congress may by general Laws prescribe the Manner in which such Acts, Records and Proceedings shall be proved, and the Effect thereof.</p> <p>Which means every state MUST recognize the laws (public acts) and judicial proceedings (permits and licenses) of every other state.   Can you image New York refusing to recognize a drivers&#8217; license from Virginia or Vermont?  Or a marrige certificate from Ohio?   That is exactly what these states are doing by refusing to recognize other states&#8217; licenses and permits.</p> <p>Why doesn&#8217;t the NRA or some other large organization file suit to enforce the Constitution, which the do-gooder politicians are deliberately flouting?   After all, any law or regulation that contradicts the national Constitution is automatically null and void</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-165">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-165" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-165">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-165">Gryryder</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-165" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-165" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>The politicians of Illinois have never heard of or totally understand the purpose of and/or the rights of American citizens as so provided  the US Constitution. They only care what is proper for their individual self and/or party policy. They fail to understand the purpose of the Oath of Office that they took to preserve and protect. </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" A vast majority of our founding fathers were deists and against organized religion. They believed in a &#8220;creator&#8221;, but they also believed in separating church and state. Read the 1st Amendment! Our original seal of the US can be found on the back of a one dollar bill, in it you will find what the founding fathers intended. The statement in Latin is &#8220;NOVUS ORDO SECLORUM&#8221;, translated to English, it reads &#8220;A NEW SECULAR ORDER&#8221;. Secular is defined below:<br /> 1.of or pertaining to worldly things or to things that are not regarded as religious, spiritual, or sacred; temporal: secular interests.<br /> 2.not pertaining to or connected with religion.<br /> 3. concerned with nonreligious subjects.</p> <p>So what I&#8217;m basically saying is: Read and study your history before you spout all of the God and founding father stuff. </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-1055">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1055" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1055">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1055">truthseeker</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1055" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1055" class="dsq-comment-message"><p> That&#8217;s an absolute revisionist falsehood, and you have fallen for it and have failed to learn the history of this country.  Some founding fathers were &#8220;diests,&#8221; but not in the modern sense of that term, and they certainly did not set out to create a secular paradise as revisionists in the NEA now teach.  They were deeply religious men, and even the most secular of them, Ben Franklin, said things about the truth of God and Christianity that would shock the modern liberal or athiest.  The founding fathers were against a state-run religion like the Church of England, but said publicly many times that democracy depends on Christianity to survive. Get educated.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-1542">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1542" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1542">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1542">Steve Bumgardner</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1542" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1542" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Sorry &#8220;truthseeker&#8221; back to school for you. Franklin was responding to a stalemate. He was offering an elaborate insult: If you guys can&#8217;t do it, pray to one who can. It worked. Several of them got their knickers in a pretty tight knot over the comment, but they compromised and got the job done.</p> <p>Funny someone calling himself &#8220;truthseeker&#8221; should snipe about revisionist history while offering revisionist history. Not really all that interested in truth, eh?</p> <p>Oh, and it was the Continental Convention of 1787. They didn&#8217;t call it the &#8220;Constitutional Convention&#8221; because they didn&#8217;t want folks to know what they were up to until it was pretty much done.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-1638">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1638" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1638">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1638">amhistoryprof</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1638" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1638" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Abosolutely True an very well put. Amen!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-2965">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-2965" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-2965">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-2965">wonder worm</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-2965" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-2965" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>where did they say this? then why isnt it in the constitution?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-1056">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1056" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1056">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1056">truthseeker</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1056" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1056" class="dsq-comment-message"><p> Here&#8217;s a snippet&#8211; the &#8220;athiest&#8221; or &#8220;secularist&#8221; Benjamin Franklin to the Constitutional Convention:<br /> &#8220;In this situation of this Assembly, groping as it were in the dark to<br /> find political truth, and scarce able to distinguish it when presented<br /> ot us, how has it happened, Sir, that we have not hitherto once thought<br /> of humbly applying to the Father of lights to illuminate our<br /> understanding?</p> <p>In the beginning of the Contest with G. Britain, when we were sensible<br /> of danger, we had daily prayer in this room for Divine protection. &#8211; Our<br />  prayers, Sir, were heard, &amp; they were graciousy answered.  All of<br /> us who were engaged in the struggle must have observed frequent<br /> instances of a superintending Providence in our favor.</p> <p>To that kind Providence we owe this happy opportunity of consulting in<br /> peace on the means of establishing our future national felicity.  And<br /> have we now forgotten that powerful Friend? or do we imagine we no<br /> longer need His assistance?</p> <p>I have lived, Sir, a long time, and the longer I live, the more<br /> convincing proofs I see of this truth &#8211; That God Governs in the affairs<br /> of men.  And if a sparrow cannot fall to the ground without His notice,<br /> is it probable that an empire can rise without His aid?</p> <p>We have been assured, Sir, in the Sacred Writings, that &#8220;except the Lord<br />  build the House, they labor in vain that build it.&#8221;  I firmly believe<br /> this; and I also believe that without his concurring aid we shall<br /> succeed in this political building no better than the Builders of Babel:<br />   We shall be divided by our partial local interests; our projects will<br /> be confounded, and we ourselves shall become a reproach and bye word<br /> down to future ages.</p> <p>And what is worse, mankind may hereafter from this unfortunate instance,<br />  despair of establishing Governments by human wisdom and leave it to<br /> chance, war and conquest.</p> <p>I therefore beg leave to move &#8211; that henceforth prayers imploring the<br /> assistance of Heaven, and its blessing on our deliberations, be held in<br /> this Assembly every morning before we proceed to business, and that one<br /> or more of the clergy of this city be requested to officiate in that<br /> service.&#8221;</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-1587">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1587" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1587">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1587">B1itsjustme</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1587" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1587" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>That sir is incorrect and you probably know it. B. Franklin had a fellow Pennsylvanian read this to the congress before passage&#8230;.</p> <p>&#8221;<br /> Mr. President</p> <p>I confess that there are several parts of this constitution which I do not<br /> at present approve, but I am not sure I shall never approve them: For having<br /> lived long, I have experienced many instances of being obliged by better<br /> information, or fuller consideration, to change opinions even on important<br /> subjects, which I once thought right, but found to be otherwise. It is<br /> therefore that the older I grow, the more apt I am to doubt my own judgment,<br /> and to pay more respect to the judgment of others. Most men indeed as well as<br /> most sects in Religion, think themselves in possession of all truth, and that<br /> wherever others differ from them it is so far error. Steele a Protestant in a<br /> Dedication tells the Pope, that the only difference between our Churches in<br /> their opinions of the certainty of their doctrines is, the Church of Rome is<br /> infallible and the Church of England is never in the wrong. But though many<br /> private persons think almost as highly of their own infallibility as of that of<br /> their sect, few express it so naturally as a certain french lady, who in a<br /> dispute with her sister, said &#8220;I don&#8217;t know how it happens, Sister but I meet<br /> with no body but myself, that&#8217;s always in the right — Il n&#8217;y a que moi<br /> qui a toujours raison.&#8221;</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-2964">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-2964" Or a dem that wants waiting periods at gun shows to take that idiotic loophole out of play. (I am a dem who bought a nice beretta at a gun show) There are more dems like me than not. I&#8217;m also a dem that is secular but respectful of other religions, the plural. This country was founded on pluralism. If you don&#8217;t believe that, look it up. As far as not changing something that has worked for years, I&#8217;m not sure I follow that. Are we talking guns, which you have to admit needs something done. God? Hell that changes all the time. Or slavery? Should we have left that alone?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-1647">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1647" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1647">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1647">Jtfkf</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1647" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1647" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>1 Quick answer.Theres good and bad in everything on this planet earth.&#8221; Bad cars&#8230;.good cars.&#8221; Example: I Own a CCL from Texas, I like the feeling of being safe for my family, when we go out to eat at night or day.The Police are over worked and under paid. Deism was a popular religion during the Enlightenment period. FYI, Deism is not a form of Christianity.</p> <p>Yes, Franklin said the things &#8220;truthseeker&#8221; said. In the end they didn&#8217;t offer up so much as one prayer during the Continental Convention. Not one.</p> <p>You know, if you try you can look this up in legitimate sources. I suggest you read &#8220;The Great Rehearsal&#8221; by Carl VanDoren. It was written before historical revisionism became so popular.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-1592">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1592" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1592">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1592">NippiDipper</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1592" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1592" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>What a maroon! </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-1639">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1639" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1639">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1639">amhistoryprof</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1639" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1639" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>So you are saying that everything in the constitution, including your exercision of the 1st ammendment here, is worth getting behind EXCEPT the 2nd ammendment? Of those that could/should, there are those who should not be allowed to carry a firearm&#8211; openly or concealed.</p> <p> There are persons who entered military service as a &#8216;last resort&#8217;. Some, being raised and indoctrinated into a religion or mindset&#8211; do so out of idealism and/or belief. None of which precludes them being idiots, stupid, nor thrill seeking freaks as possibly implied above by others.</p> <p> Thank you to those who served. There are conflicts that I have not agreed with that they have participated in&#8230; Our opinions are our own, and sacred. The intent is everything.</p> <p> I am a well trained near pacifist who owns a gun, and has a permit to carry concealed. Whether I carry or not isn&#8217;t the point, I can if I feel it necessary, and have the right to do so. I am highly educated, have healthy respect for the powerful responsibility that comes with such a right&#8230;</p> <p> Someone above stating that criminals have all the firepower vs law abiding citizen is correct.. ASK the Brit who owns the weapons in England&#8230; Not the Police officers, not the competent citizen&#8212; No! The criminal. He/She will have much to say about that.</p> <p> To sum up: There are persons not fit mentally/psychologically prepared, fit, or mature with regards to the responsible use/ownership of a weapon&#8211; firearm or otherwise. There are laws and checks-and-balances to help that disparity.</p> <p> Removing the rights of everyone means giving Carte-Blanche to the criminal faction, and empowering them many fold&#8230; </p> <p> Keep in mind, just because someone passed their act 240 with psych exam to be a police officer, does not make them sane, or able&#8230; Too many have abused their power.<br />  <br />  Call me names (1st Amendment), own a gun (2nd), fight illegal search of person, home papers ( 4th), and do not incriminate yourself (5th)&#8230; Freedom is not a pick and choose thing! You cannot decide today, this is acceptable, then tomorrow you want it back or gone&#8230; Give it some thought!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-3118">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-3118" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-3118">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-3118">Thanks#2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-3118" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-3118" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>WOW&#8230;. This is no less or no more than teachers do, machinists do, firefighters do&#8230; are you going to call for their rights to be infringed?<br /> Look to the message (without reading your own bias into it) and not the passion with which it&#8217;s delivered.<br /> Given the choice between a passionate supporter of my rights (wildmangood2000) and someone who&#8217;s quick to jump on the &#8216;for me but not thee&#8217; bandwagon without supporting evidence (Dellavar), I&#8217;d much rather arm wildmangood2000. He&#8217;ll speak up for me if someone tries to do me wrong. I doubt I&#8217;m alone on that score.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-3047">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-3047" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-3047">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-3047">Taco_Friendly</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-3047" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-3047" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Dellavar; you fail. gtfo. noob.<br /> Wildmangood2k; its called the NRA.<br /> Dbluefish; lowrider is expressing his opinion and should not be subjected to your closed-mindedness xD<br /> everyone else: dont feed the trolls</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-3238">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-3238" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-3238">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-3238">Wcj0616</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-3238" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-3238" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I bet you voted for Oracko Bahama</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-3931">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-3931" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-3931">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-3931">ARMED IN CHICAGO</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-3931" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-3931" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Moron, let me refresh your failing memory. Further, no permit is required AT ALL, of residents or non-residents alike, to carry concealed in most places within the state. There are a few exceptions to this, CCW holders can carry in a few places non-holders can not and there are places, such as courtrooms, federal buildings, etc&#8230; where NO ONE other than L.E. can carry. Refer to AZDPS website for details.</p> <p>All in all, the AZ Resident Permit is currently the most recognized in the nation.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-1571">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1571" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1571">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1571">Charie</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1571" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1571" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Wildmangood, there is already a &#8220;union&#8221; for gun owner rights. It is the National Rifle Association<br /> (NRA). They are guarding your gun owner rights and are primarily the reason many states allow concealed carry. Everyone who feels that the second amendment is important should belong the this organization. </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-1591">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1591" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1591">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1591">Djmw</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1591" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1591" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>While Hawaii does have a &#8220;may issue&#8221; law, I&#8217; don&#8217;t believe it is actually possible to obtain a concealed carry permit.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-1627">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-1627" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-1627">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-1627">Smgouch</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-1627" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-1627" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Gents,<br /> A lot of you seem to have forgotten that your comments should be about gun rights.  I am a lady who has had guns sinces the age of 10.  I have a nice collection in my gun safe from handguns to rifles.  I like to target practice and hunt but age and a bum knee have put a temporary hold on that activity.  I have had concealed carry permits both in the state of Oregon and Washington since the age of 22 (now 65).  Protect your rights, practice gun safety, teach your children gun respect,and use the political machine to change what you don&#8217;t approve!<br /> sgn</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-4203">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4203" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-4203">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-4203">CharonPDX</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4203" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4203" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I am curious how you have had concealed carry permits in Oregon and Washington for 43 years, when the Oregon has only OFFERED concealed carry permits for 22 years&#8230; class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-2898">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-2898">CharonPDX</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div it&#8230;</p> <p>Oregon is a &#8220;shall issue to residents, MAY issue to non-residents.&#8221;  If you&#8217;re a non-resident, you have to give a &#8220;compelling reason&#8221; why you want one.  And you have to live in a directly bordering state (Washington, Idaho, Nevada, California only.)  It&#8217;s up to the individual Oregon county sheriff&#8217;s offices to decide where in the bordering states they accept from, so if you&#8217;re in a bordering area near multiple Oregon counties, you can pick the one you think will be more likely to grant.)  For example, Multnomah county will only accept applications from Washington residents (specifically those who live near Multnomah county, although they don&#8217;t detail the exact requirements.)  Clatsop county specifically says they accept from &#8220;Pacific, Grays Harbor or Wahkiakum County Washington&#8221;  But it appears that Tillamook county (which is on the coast and doesn&#8217;t border any other states,) will consider applications from ANY bordering state!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-2907">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-2907" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-2907">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-2907">Mel</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-2907" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-2907" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>As of 8-15-2-11, Louisiana does not honor Florida non resident permits for residents of Louisiana.  I think l got that right.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-2908">         <div I researched this 2 yrs ago and all the replies stated that gun laws for cmv were regulated by the state.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-5079">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5079" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5079">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5079">Scheib</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5079" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5079" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>In accordance with DOT 173.54 Forbidden Explosives, subparagraph (f) states:(f) A loaded firearm (except as providedin 49 CFR 1544.21949 CFR Pertains to Aviation Personnel and those allowed to Carry on Commerdial Aircraft</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-15025">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-15025" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-15025">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-15025">MadmaxUSA</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-15025" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-15025" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Thanks for the research but I believe that 49 CFR 1544.21949 pertains to common carriers or other businesses who transport &#8220;Forbidden Explosives&#8221; for profit. Didnt have my gun so no prob but that is what he said was ok if I did have it.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-4917">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4917" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-4917">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-4917">Mgrumpyone</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4917" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4917" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Scottyjneilson: CLIP? Really, do you live in a fantasy world? What gun do you have that you have to remove a &#8220;Clip&#8221; from? All the weapons I come across these days use a magazine.<br /> A clip is a device that is used to store multiple rounds of<br /> ammunition together as a unit, ready for insertion into the magazine or<br /> cylinder of a firearm.<br />  This speeds up the process of loading and reloading the firearm as<br /> several rounds can be loaded at once, rather than one round being loaded<br />  at a time. Several different types of clips exist, most of which are<br /> made of inexpensive metal stampings that are designed to be disposable,<br /> though they are often re-used.</p> <p>The term clip is commonly used to describe a firearm magazine,<br />  though this usage is technically incorrect. In the correct usage, a<br /> clip is used to feed a magazine or revolving cylinder, while a magazine<br /> or a belt is used to load cartridges into the chamber of a firearm</p> </div>         </div> case unloaded</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-5196">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5196" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5196">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5196">M203</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5196" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5196" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>dont know about other states, but from florida to michigan you can take I75 with your pistol in your holster, LOADED , and on your person.  if you get pulled over tell the officer right away that you have ccw out of fl.  and your weapon is secured with you.  and how would he like to procede.  also have your ccw out and ready id="dsq-comment-5317">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5317" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5317"> http://www.facebook.com/matthew.korcek                <span id="dsq-author-user-5317">Matthew Korcek</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5317" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5317" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>@Theglims &#8211; While there is a Federal<br />  Law that protects you while transporting your weapon from The state you<br />  are legal in and the state you are going that you will be Legal in, it<br /> is up to each state as to weather they honor that Federal Law or not.   I<br />  Recently needed to go through California on my way to Oregon, so I<br /> contacted CHP.  I own a Taurus Judge, which I had heard was considered<br /> an Assault Weapon in California, and therefore illegal.  I was told by<br /> CHP, that, regardless of the Federal Laws, if I was stopped for some<br /> reason and my weapon was found, locked or not, that it was up to the<br /> individual Officer.  I would most likely be charged with a Felony,<br /> regardless of the fact that There is a Federal Law protecting me to<br /> transport from My previous state to Oregon.  So best bet, contact the<br /> State Police / Highway Patrol of each state you plan to drive through.</p>    <div id="dsq-comment-body-4382" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4382" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>How do you legally carry a hangun through Ilinois if you are </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-4692">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4692" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-4692">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-4692">Camper_mike</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4692" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4692" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I used to live in Illinois.  I moved so I could have my constitutional rights back.  Anyway, their law says the gun must be unloaded (clip removed) and placed in a closed container, eg. gun case, box, etc.  You are not required to unload the magazine, just the gun.  If you are a resident you must have a FOID (Firearms Owners Identification Card) to own a firearm.  If the gun is not loaded and completely encased you are legal.  Open carry is illegal in Illinois.  Put it in a case, unload it, and put it on the seat.  </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even        <cite id="dsq-cite-4485"> http://www.facebook.com/todd.cherveny                <span id="dsq-author-user-4485">Todd Cherveny Jr</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4485" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4485" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>you have a permit to carry mn also does not have a concealment mandate in their law though they would prefer  that you carry concealed they left that &#8220;loophole&#8221; their so if for example your carrying in a shoulder rig and your walking down the street when a gust of wind blows your jacket open and other pedestrians see the firearm that can be considered open carry and in sme states you can get in trouble for it mn and in didnt want there residents to have that concern</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-4418">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4418" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-4418">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-4418">Garry Evans</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4418" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4418" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I will be traveling from Virginia to Florida. How do I legally carry a handgun through Georgia?</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-4425">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4425" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-4425">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-4425">KC</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4425" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4425" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Do you have a permit from your *home state* where you are a resident that allows you to carry in Georgia?  If so, you needn&#8217;t do a thing.  If not, you will have to stop outside of the state line of Georgia, unload your firearm and place the firearm in a container.  Keep all ammo/magazines stores in a separate location (I would STRONGLY advise you keep the magazines unloaded!) and the container should be one that locks.  </p> <p>My suggestion is: store the firearm and ammo/magazines in such a fashion that gives no one a reason to suspect you can quickly arm yourself.  </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-4420">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4420" class="dsq-comment-header"> I think this issue has been overlooked and it should be addressed.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-4490">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4490" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-4490">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-4490">Speidell</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4490" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4490" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Does Maine accept Pennsylvania&#8217;s non resident license. I get conflicting answers from the agencies in Maine.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-4492">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4492" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-4492">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-4492">Billspider</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4492" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4492" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I received an answer from Maine. They will not honor any  states non resident license, except their own non resident license.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-4503">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4503" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-4503">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-4503">Jakester</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4503" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4503" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>With a &#8220;Rights Denied&#8221; state like Illinois&#8230;it was said that a handgun must be &#8220;unloaded and in a locked container&#8221;.  My question would be&#8230;</p> <p>Can the container be non-locking if a lock is placed on the gun itself?  As in a trigger lock or a lock that passes through the ejector?  I ask because my case does not lock and I would rather not buy a new one.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-4504">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-4504" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-4504">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-4504">DoctorJ</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-4504" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4504" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>This map shows why this type of permit should be a a Federal Nation-Wide permit, so as to eliminate all the differences and ocnfusion as to where you are legal and where you are not.   <div id="dsq-comment-body-4552" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-4552" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>It&#8217;s a good thing guns are so hard to get in Chicago&#8230;because crime is so low and the locals are so non-violent. It&#8217;s funny how that works out. Places that understand that restrictions on liberties HAVE to be justified by need and not by the &#8220;feelings&#8221; of some anti-gun politicians. When my Sheriff greatly liberalized the critieria for a CCW, as a police officer, I was concerned that we&#8217;d get some stupid behavior by gun toting  hot dogs. Fact was, we did not see one out of a thousand permits mis-used. If there was some quetionable judgement- the Sheriff pulled the permit and required the permitee to justify the behavior. That&#8217;s more control than the anti-gunners have&#8230;and it doesn&#8217;t create criminals- something Illinois has enough of despite their visionary gun policies. Those folks can&#8217;t get a Governor that stays out of jail.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-4553"> I gotta say, you sound little like a guy in my concealed carry class who outright admitted that the basic reason he was getting a permit to carry concealed was because he couldn&#8217;t *wait* to shoot someone!  Everything he found out that he *wasn&#8217;t* gonna be allowed to do with a C.C. permit p!ssed him off &#8211; or so it seemed.  Needless to say, he was excused from the class about half-way thru it &#8211; no refund! &#8211; and a report was filed with the authorities in his town and county for follow-up.  He&#8217;ll likely never be issued a C.C. permit, either.</p> <p>I&#8217;ve yet to hear of *any* State putting the issue of whether to allow concealed carry up to the general population on a voter referendum &#8230; therefore, you&#8217;re likely avoiding any number of  States chock-full of people who don&#8217;t like it either.  Most State legislatures take it upon themselves to decide on the issue of full concealed-carry &#8211; and whether to reciprocate with residents of other States.Most highly liberal States are those most likely to make sure the criminals have more rights than you do.  Even if they do have some sort of concealed-carry law, they likely want to keep as tight of a control on it as possible &#8211; including the matter of reciprocation.  Don&#8217;t avoid going to those States by wasting your valuable time and spending money you don&#8217;t need to on fuel, etc. &#8211; you really make yourself sound terribly childish with such comments &#8211; just go where you have to, get thru it as quickly (and as legally!) as possible, make things easy, quick and simple &#8211; *always* be alert when and if you stop &#8211; and avoid situations where you won&#8217;t NEED to use a concealed weapon.</p> <p>If you&#8217;re gonna intentionally drive into a no-no State and wait until you&#8217;re out of gas, then fill up at a remote gas station at 2 a.m. &#8211; kinda-sorta hoping you get confronted &#8230;. well, NO State want people like you in it &#8211; ever! &#8211; and neither would most law-abiding citizens anywhere.</p> <p>You might think about growing up a little more, sport.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-5195">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5195" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5195">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5195">M203</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5195" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5195" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>hey GlocksRock&#8230; </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-5576">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5576" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5576">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5576">Bob b</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5576" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5576" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Hmmmm, interesting.   I carry a concealed weapon every day.  I own a store and will not be there without a gun.  Way too many strange folks wander in.  I don&#8217;t carry with the goal to some day shoot someone.  In fact, I sincerely hope it will never be used..  I simply don&#8217;t want to be standing there when some @#@#$@  tries to take what we have earned at the point of a gun and me unprepared.  Bob1701a is free to make what ever choice he desires, but he will miss a lot of neat places in the country. </p> <p>Let&#8217;s be realistic.  Concealed carry is a very big responsibility.   The consequences of your actions can be significant.  I think it is an individual choice, and, you are right, some folks shouldn&#8217;t carry.  They are simply too reactionary.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-5595">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5595" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5595">                 <span commend anyone who stands up for their beliefs and does something more than just cries about it.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-5597">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5597" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5597">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5597">Daily Llama</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5597" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5597" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I agree!  I was over-exuberant in my original criticism.  I apologize to everyone offended.</p> <p>The problem is &#8230; one person raging against &#8220;the system&#8221; comes across to many as just another a nut.  To change laws and governments, we all need to support a united front!  Let&#8217;s let the NRA speak for us.  If you haven&#8217;t joined, please do!!!  </p> <p>I just finished my concealed carry class and was pretty horrified by who started out in the class.  We started out with 15 showing up.  9 completed the requirements.</p> <p>1.  One guy didn&#8217;t even bring a firearm with him &#8211; and had no intention of renting one or even firing one.  He said he would simply demanded a permit after taking the course and the tests &#8211; &#8220;because&#8221;.  He was excused.  FAIL!</p> <p>2.  Another guy was excused just before the noon linch break when he found out the course DID NOT include food.  Some do, some don&#8217;t.  He whined and made a rather loud &#8220;stage whisper&#8221; that someone who rips people off like that &#8211; and it wasn&#8217;t a rip-off at all, HE mis-understood the rules of the course &#8211; &#8220;could be shot for that and who&#8217;d complain?&#8221;.  FAIL!  The police came and he left with them.  I understand they had a &#8220;nice&#8221; talk in the parking lot &#8230;</p> <p>3.  Two guys showed up right from the get-go with loaded weapons &#8211; ONE WAS EVEN ROUND-CHAMBERED, COCKED AND OFF-SAFETY!!!  FAIL!!!!</p> <p>4.  One other guy showed up carrying a revolver tucked in the waist-band of his jeans &#8211; FULLY CONCEALED and ILLEGAL!!!  It *was* unloaded but still &#8230;.  FAIL!!!!</p> <p>5.  The final drop-out claimed an &#8220;emergency&#8221; and left after lunch-break and without any further reason for leaving &#8230; and didn&#8217;t ask about a refund, said the instructor.</p> <p>Sorry, but these 6 people came across as having more than a few screws loose!  I was wrong in automatically categorizing the original poster in the same class as these VERY strange people.  The rest of us were eyes open and mouths shut.  We were there to learn, NOT criticize and complain.</p> <p>Maybe I&#8217;m just taking this hand-gun ownership and concealed-carry business too seriously &#8230;</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-5" The only problems is, I live in California. Is there a way to legaly purchase one or is it back to the &#8220;black market&#8221;?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-5048">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5048" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5048">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5048">Caledurago</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5048" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5048" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Ok so you can&#8217;t carry in a given state, does any state forbid having a flair gun(for signaling) in an emergency? And what fool would want to find out what damage a 12 gague flair gun would do.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-5075">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5075" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5075">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5075">Chucktripleh</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5075" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5075" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>The California Shall Issue Concealed Carry Proposition will allow any applicant who can legally own a firearm to also have a permit to carry a concealed handgun after they pay a reasonable application fee and complete a two day course provided by an instructor who is certified by the State of California to teach the course. The permit SHALL be issued with no other unreasonable requirements, such as political contributions, celebrity status, or other restrictions. Front Sight Training in Las Vegas is supporting, and in fact assisting, in the gathering of signatures to get a Shall Issue Concealed Carry Proposition on the November, 2012 General Election Ballot in California. In 1986 only 7 states had shall issue. Now 38 states have shall issue and another 4 states have no restrictions.  </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-5083">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5083" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5083">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5083">Burkesid76</span> individual permit for each state?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-5091">         <div class="dsq-comment-message"><p>@Theglims &#8211; While there is a Federal Law that protects you while transporting your weapon from The state you are legal in and the state you are going that you will be Legal in, it is up to each state as to weather they honor that Federal Law or not.   I Recently needed to go through California on my way to Oregon, so I contacted CHP.  I own a Taurus Judge, which I had heard was considered an Assault Weapon in California, and therefore illegal.  I was told by CHP, that, regardless of the Federal Laws, if I was stopped for some reason and my weapon was found, locked or not, that it was up to the individual Officer.  I would most likely be charged with a Felony, regardless of the fact that There is a Federal Law protecting me to transport from My previous state to Oregon.  So best bet, contact the State Police / Highway Patrol of each state you plan to drive through.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt    </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-5522">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5522" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5522">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5522">Nick</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5522" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5522" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Mike you&#8217;re wrong. Second Amendment applied to all 50 states equally, so everyone can travel throughout the United States and still preserve their rights. Second Amendment doesn&#8217;t say anything about crossing state border lines. </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-5543">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5543" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5543">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5543">JoePublic</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5543" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5543" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You are on the right track.  According to the US Supreme Court, the Second Amendment applies to all States, as incorporated through the 14th Amendment.  However, the US Supreme Court narrowly decided that issue by a 5-4 vote in 2010 in McDonald v. Chicago.  In other words, if we lose one &#8220;conservative&#8221; member on the Court, bye bye gun rights.  Plain and simple.  </p> <p>So, while what you are saying should be correct, in reality the Courts have allowed the government (local, state, and federal) to slowly whittle away our fundamental constitutional rights if what the government is attempting to do is a &#8220;compelling governmental interest.&#8221;  As long as the Court can construe what the government is doing is &#8220;narrowly tailored&#8221; to achieve that interest and it is using the &#8220;least restrictive means&#8221; possible, then it will be found to be lawful.  This has been going on for the past one hundred years and is in large part why this country is so screwed up.  Most people have no clue that our rights can be so easily violated.  I fear that it may already too late to wake them up.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" non resident.  So much for the bill of rights</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-5594">         <div those &#8220;flaws.&#8221;  Wonder why?</p> <p>An Obama appointee, US Federal Court Judge Myerscough, ruled a few days ago that the 2nd Amendment does not give citizens the right to carry firearms in public.</p> <p>Operation Fast and Furious.  Enough said.  I could go on and on.  We can either see the writing on the wall or continue to support politicians who happen to have a D or R next to their name.  </p> <p>You draw your own conclusions.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-5899">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5899" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5899"> http://pulse.yahoo.com/_GDO6RZAC4MRYYGB4OG5SD4TOJA                <span id="dsq-author-user-5899">Tallen</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5899" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5899" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>What does the Second Amendment state about &#8220;Concealed&#8221;?</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-6213">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6213" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6213">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6213">StoutCortez</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6213" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6213" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Doesn&#8217;t deal with concealed carry directly. class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I would agree that &#8220;bearing arms&#8221; should be allowed anywhere but UNTIL this does not require a permit or license, it is unlikely to be recognized in every state.  Just like the practice of medicine, law, plumbing, or teaching school, which are not considered fundamental rights, a license is required by every state and they find no obligation to honor the license of other states though this be one country.  A license is permission from the issuing body for you to perform some act which would otherwise be unlawful, a trespass, or a tort.</p> <p>Not that I think its right, but that IS the way that carrying weapons it is viewed by the law. Knives may even be more restricted than firearms right now.  Until the courts honestly accept the original intent of &#8220;keep and bear arms&#8221; as an uninfringable RIGHT, the peaceable citizens are at the mercy of the distortions of the law and miscreants who have no regard for good or bad laws.</p> All logged and searchable by all law enforcement agencies nationwide. Just about all states have a tracking system to root out the fakes. If your a felon I hope you get caught if not just get your permit, it&#8217;s not that hard in the majority if states. Though I strongly believe not everyone should be able to carry, this is why I think all states should require you to shoot if not for your sake at least for the sake of other lives you could take in the heat of the moment due to lack of knowledge of your weapon.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-5849">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5849" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5849"> http://pulse.yahoo.com/_VYKEPM2YQAVBAGNRTN23PSJYJU                <span id="dsq-author-user-5849">WOP2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5849" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5849" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Training yes, absolutely, as much trigger time as possible, shoot, don&#8217;t shoot scenarios, knowing about the critical &#8220;T&#8221;, recognizing what a hand cannon will and won&#8217;t do, clearing jams/stovepipes/failure to feed, knowing YOUR gun inside out&#8211;I ABSOLUTELY AGREE! I&#8217;m not sure how this works in reality, but in theory it can be done.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-5959">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5959" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5959">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5959">Mike</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5959" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5959" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You people in New York have been brainwashed into thinking guns cause crime.  I carry and have used my gun to stop bad guys from committing crimes, and here (in Oregon) the dirtballs think twice because they dont know who is armed.  </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-5998">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5998" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5998">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5998">Daryl</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5998" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5998" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Mike, The bad guys in Oregon may not know who is armed but they certainly know who isn&#8217;t (anybody with with out-of-state tags).
