Just what Fox news kept spewing to enrage the public against anything/everything associated with the president (because he&#8217;s not a white male over 50) until it just fizzled away? </p> <p>Do you have any clue as to how many other US embassies have been attacked?</p> <p>Facts really suck when they don’t paint the picture you’re attempting to palm off on the American people. Facts are Republicans – in spite of talking like<br /> a character in a John Wayne movie – have failed and failed miserably over the<br /> past 37 years to protect Americans and America’s interest at home and abroad. </p> <p>Since 1974 – President Gerald Ford – there have been 44 terrorist attacks against American interests, as a result of which 3,154 Americans have been killed (including four ambassadors), and 18 American embassies or consulates overrun or attacked; so, with those numbers in mind, under which party’s Presidents have American interests – and citizens – suffered less?</p> <p>Fourteen (14) terrorist attacks,<br /> 263 Americans killed (including two ambassadors), five embassies/consulates<br /> overrun/attacked under Democratic Presidents.</p> <p>Thirty (30) terrorist attacks, 2,891 Americans killed (including two ambassadors), 13 embassies/consulates attacked/overrun by terrorists under Republican Presidents<br /> Details?</p> <p>-Three terrorist attacks, seven Americans killed (including two ambassadors), one embassy/consulate attacked/overrun by terrorists under Republican President Gerald Ford.   </p> <p>-Two terrorist attacks, One American (ambassador) killed, one embassy/consulate overrun under Democratic President Jimmy Carter</p> <p>-Eleven terrorist attacks,466 Americans killed, three embassies/consulates overrun/attacked under Republican President Ronald Reagan</p> <p>-Six terrorist attacks, 237 Americans killed, two embassies/consulates overrun/attacked under Democratic President Bill Clinton</p> <p>-Sixteen terrorist attacks, 2,418 Americans killed, nine embassies/consulates overrun/attacked under Republican President George W. Bush</p> <p>-Six terrorist attacks, 25 Americans killed (including one ambassador), 2 embassies/consulates overrun/attacked, under Democratic President Barrack Obama<br /> This is REAL &#8220;fair and balanced&#8221; accounting of REAL FACTS- invite you to check for yourself-  somewhere other than just Fox Noose &#8211; sorry to rub your face in the truth (no, actually I&#8217;m not sorry!)</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-21368">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-21368" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-21368">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-21368">Autocat</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-21368" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-21368" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Where else would you even hear about Benghazi? WE aren&#8217;t like that at all. It is a simple truth in this beloved nation of ours (ALL OF US) that those states with a constitutional outlook on the 2nd Amendment have a much lower crime rate. Take Alaska, for example; EVERYONE up there carries a gun. They HAVE to, due mostly to the fact that it takes law enforcement (few and far between!) a long time to reach any emergency location, and a bear or a moose attack is a likelihood if you live anywhere west of Canada. Which is anywhere in Alaska. When I was there, I found wildlife at large in all the towns, on all roads, in all the streams and backyards&#8230; there&#8217;re more of THEM than there are of US!!! And in places on the southern border, there are fewer cops than you might think because they are almost all watching the illegals trudging north, and are all spread so thin they may as well not be there if you need an ambulance or have been mugged or  otherwise assaulted. What about the Bronx? I lived there for 20 years, and a more f**ked up place I will NEVER see&#8230; unless I move to Chicago. Can you think of a better way to stop the violence, a way better than letting ALL the law-abiding folks there carry lawfully obtained handguns? With BIG A*S magazines, 15 rounds or more to a clip? I can&#8217;t, and I was a cop for 28 years there. Care to reply?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-21034">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-21034" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-21034">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-21034">carl lewis</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-21034" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-21034" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>yes sir I agree with everything you said I love my ccw aswell and appreciate the fact i can protect myself if I have to when I don&#8217;t have the option to wait for the Leo&#8217;s to come and save my life or others</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-19265">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19265" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19265">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19265">hungryHippo</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-19265" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-19265" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Well, I just read about 20 comments b4 yours and didn&#8217;t really see anyone say anything about &#8216;enjoying fighting.&#8217;  Have you seen the news lately? I live in one of the boroughs of NY, and will be relocating down south as soon as I sell my house. I have been carrying for 33 years, and the only time my gun has been fired outside of a range was in self defense. None of my weapons have ever gone on a crime spree.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-19730">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19730" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19730">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19730">billyboi57</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-19730" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-19730" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You have the username &#8220;godswill&#8221;. You&#8217;re a peach, bub! I would have never realized and internalized the scope of my loutish vulgarity without your truly eminent sagacity. </p> <p>Oh, wait! Now that I mull it over a bit, and think on it, yes, I long ago had the epiphany that I am an eternal 13-year-old boy, now trapped the fabulous middle-age clay of a Rubenesque Adonis! (Mercy Me! Bask in my glory!) Yep, I admit what I am freely and gleefully! At least I&#8217;m not a curmudgeonly tosspot who likes to insidiously insinuate words and ideas in other people&#8217;s mouths. </p> <p>When did I ever claim immunity from criticism? The only right I claim (in this particular instance) is the right to free speech. I don&#8217;t really care how anybody replies to my bombastic ranting, just as long as they accept the fact that I will possibly give back to them in kind, and with equal or accelerated verve. </p> <p>Look, I&#8217;ll shellack liberals (or conservatives, for that matter, or any other stripe of political animal) as pinko pussy willows bending whichever ways the wind blows. You can bet the animal farm in this brave new world, bucko, that I&#8217;ll paint from the palate of my myriad lexicographic vocabulary sprawling, epic. satirical masterpieces about anyone and anything that inspires the sardonic urge in me to do so, and anyone is free to do the same to me. Tit-for-rat-ta-tat-tat, baby! But then such interpid individuals can expect a literary salvo in return. Hear that whistling? That&#8217;s the shell heading your way. Better jump in your foxhole, get in the fetal position, and pray to the god of your choice, &#8217;cause the Pale Horse is a comin&#8217;, sunshine.</p> <p>Incidentally, friend, whether one is witty, clever, or glib (wickedly, righteously, or otherwise) is all in the eye of the beholder. See, just because I might hold the opinion you&#8217;re a nattering twit blither-blathering away your free time (I mean, the same could be said of me) does not mean that there isn&#8217;t a pretentious brain-trust floating out there in the nebulous ether that absolutely thinks you are pregnant and dripping with fecund profundity. </p> <p>However, this hypothetical beacon of cognitive prowess might want to replace the flickering 10-watt filament illuminating their myopic, microcosmic lighthouse. In any event, you keep on keepin&#8217; on there, chuckles. I&#8217;m sure there are a few mendacious souls out there who will appreciate your pharisaical and opprobrious rhetoric. Excelsior!</p> <p>(Ball&#8217;s in your court, sweetheart. Let&#8217;s see whether you have a strong backhand, or just a limp wrist. Mac</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12557" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12557" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>The 2nd Amendment was designed for the specific purpose you stated, but guns are not a requisite to wage war; in fact, they would really have little relevance in overthrowing a regime or foreign invasion in today&#8217;s world. I&#8217;m completely opposed to banning guns or severely controlling them, but I don&#8217;t see them as a crucial asset for asymmetrical tactics that are more effective than anything an armed militia could come up with.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-12841">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-12841" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-12841">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-12841">Gandalf</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12841" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12841" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Here&#8217;s the difference.  Millions of guns and hundreds of millions of rounds of ammunition are all ready out there, in the hands of the people.  Whether &#8220;the people&#8221; know it or not, they are an available paramilitary resource that can be called upon if necessary to resist a foreing invader, or can also be (if they have the will) assembled and used to resist a domestic government bent upon tyranny.<br /> On the other hand, explosives are tightly monitored, controlled, and in many cases chemically &#8220;tagged&#8221; so that they can be traced.  The  &#8220;explosives&#8221; used in the WTC attack were aircraft commandeered by hijackers. and with all the new so-called security and domestic spying laws (yes, I said domestic spying&#8230;don&#8217;t kid youself that it&#8217;s anything else) now in place, repeating this type of attack is much more difficult).  I&#8217;m willing to bet that the government is a heck of a lot more worried about the millions of firearms out here in civilian hands (many of which are untraceable because they were acquired privately without forms, background checks etc) than they are about some future &#8220;unibomber&#8221; &#8211; types with a car bomb which would be few and far between.  This is as it should be.  The government should be scared of the people.  It&#8217;s a Hell of a lot better for the people that way than the other way around.  If you don&#8217;t believe that, just ask the German Jews massacred by the Nazis, or the Cambodians who suffered and were butchered under Pol Pot&#8217;s regime&#8230;Oh wait, you  can&#8217;t:  there all dead; millions of them.  Wonder if any of them would have liked a chance to at least go down fighting with an &#8220;evil gun&#8221; in their hands and a &#8220;2nd Ammendment&#8221; that would have helped protect their right to live.  Yeah, I know, it can&#8217;t happen here; this is America.  I&#8217;m sure there were lots of Romans who believe that as well&#8230;right up to the point where the barbarians began sacking the city.  Several other civilizations/empires probably fealt that way too and, like the Romans, they&#8217;re long dead, too.<br /> Contrast the long dead civilizations above with the Swiss who&#8217;ve remained armed, neutral and FREE for over a thousand years.  What do they know that our modern day anti-gun types don&#8217;t?  Be honest with yourself and you&#8217;ll see the answer.  But, here&#8217;s the answer on Swiss citizen-soldier gave.  While observing Swiss military maneuvers, the German Kaiser once remarked to a Swiss soldier(I&#8217;m paraphrasing, now), &#8220;Your military is impresssive; highly motivated and well trained.  However, you are only  500,000.  What will you do if we Germans attack with a million men? &#8221;  The Swiss soldier thought for second and then replied, &#8220;We will shoot twice and then go home.&#8221;  If you can understand the motivation of that Swiss soldier, you can understand why we need the 2nd Ammendment.  If you cannot, then you will never &#8220;get it&#8221;.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-13434">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-13434" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-13434">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-13434">JRedHorse</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-13434" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-13434" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Excellent  post! and may I add another race of people destroyed because we were disarmed first ,my ancestors The Native Americans!<br /> The Government disarmed us once but it will NOT happen again because we now teach all our young people how to handle and use fire arms for hunting and self preservation.<br /> Thank you for a clear thinking view on a great subject!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-14534">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14534" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14534"> http://www.facebook.com/people/Ra-Hensel/1807876924                <span id="dsq-author-user-14534">R.a. The shop was full of customers and a uniformed officer was standing at the counter. Upon seeing the officer, the would-be robber announced a hold-up and fired a few wild shots from a target pistol.<br /> The officer and a clerk promptly returned fire, and several customers also drew their guns and fired. The robber was pronounced dead at the scene by Paramedics. Crime scene investigators located 47 expended cartridge cases in the shop. The subsequent autopsy revealed 23 gunshot wounds. Ballistics identified rounds from 7 different weapons. No one else was hurt. </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-14532">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14532" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14532"> http://www.facebook.com/people/Ra-Hensel/1807876924                <span id="dsq-author-user-14532">R.a.        <div id="dsq-comment-message-8476" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I too live in NY &#8211; the STATE, not the CITY.  My county possibly has more diary cows than people.  I am college educated but hunt and shoot.  Most people think that only hlllbillys and rednecks have firearms.  I have a CCW for NY, PA, UT, and others.  Most of my college educated friends also have CCW (here we actually call them Pistol Permits).  I own a 50 BMG and enjoy shooting from .22 Short up to the 50.  I can shoot during my lunch hour if I choose to do so.  That does not make me brainwashed, that makes me able to make a decision to do what I wish to do, when I wish to do it.  I&#8217;ve never had to use anything I&#8217;ve carried to stop a bad guy, and hope I never need to do so.  The violent crime in the area I live in is very low, and my county issues many permits.  Is there a relationship?  I don&#8217;t know about here, but statistics for other states say there is.</p> </div> Here in PA, we have a statutory Firearms Preemptions Law that prevents local municipalities, boros, unicorporated areas, or even big cities from passing their own laws. Philadelphia has been spanked several times for throwing their weight around on this, and the last time it cost them 25 grand. Not a lot of money, of course, but its the principle of the Preemption statute. I would suggest you look into passing the same into law in New York. purchase a firearm (long-gun or hand-gun), if you have been convicted of any crime that is punishable to 1 year or more, you are disqualified (can be appealed).  Those with documented mental illness or those who are documented with violent crimes are disqualified (NO appeal).  All applications for a concealled carry permit must go through a background check&#8230;.it doesnt rely solely on the Sheriff.  </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-6068">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6068" class="dsq-comment-header"> The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania is a true &#8220;shall issue&#8221; jurisdiction, issues a License to Carry Firearms, and does not require fingerprints. I cannot speak to other states Permits, Licenses, CCW&#8217;s, or whatever moniker they choose to use, with the exception of Utah. Utah requires training, and fingerprints, and does indeed send them to the FBI for a crosscheck.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-9945">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9945" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9945">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9945">Barcelo</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9945" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9945" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>PA issues permits by county. You have to apply to your own local sheriff and each one I hear does things a little different. When I did live in PA, I never applied for a permit, but I did hear about people applying, and they had to have a photo taken and their fingerprints taken. The state says an NCIS check has to be run on every applicant and I don&#8217;t see how that can be done without prints being taken.</p> <p>A simple search of the requirements to receive a CCW in PA will show you that fingerprints are required in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-9228">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9228" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9228">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9228">Barcelo</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9228" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9228" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I didn&#8217;t read all of the responses to this, but I didn&#8217;t see anyone point out that the basis for this argument is incorrect. I used to live in NY, now I live in Florida. When I applied for my CCW in NY, I had to submit prints, provide like three references, pay a fee, and wait. In Florida, when I applied for a CCW, I had to submit prints, take a safety course, pay a fee, and wait. I don&#8217;t know of any state that issues a permit without fingerprints and having an FBI background check done. There are a couple states that allow residents to carry concealed weapons without a permit or license, but they don&#8217;t issue, so those two or three states don&#8217;t count.</p> <p>The entire argument is based on the false belief that other states only ask for a date of birth and ID. Every state that issues a license/permit take fingerprints and run them through the FBI. A quick internet search will provide you with the requirements to obtain a CCW, so don&#8217;t take my word for it, check for yourself instead of listening to what NY politicians tell you, or what the NY news reporters tell you.</p> <p>In Florida, I have to renew and have my prints run every seven years, in NY, it was a lifetime permit that only expires if you get arrested or move out of the state. So, you might want to base your opinions on fact rather than rhetoric.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-9378">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9378" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9378">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9378">Americal</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9378" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9378" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Georgia also does fingerprints..As far as i know that is required as part of the background check</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-9514">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9514" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9514">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9514">dave_j</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9514" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9514" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I seriously doubt anyone is arguing in favor of giving felons, children, or the mentally ill concealed carry permits.  New York has a long history of irrational gun laws&#8230;until a few years ago, they wouldn&#8217;t even allow police officers from out of state to carry there!  Regardless of what your stereotypical New York superiority complex may have led you to believe, the rest of the country isn&#8217;t some backwater, and the vast majority of jurisdictions aren&#8217;t just running a background check based on whatever name and DOB someone might provide.  Nearly all require fingerprints at a minimum.  Frankly, it disturbs me a bit that any jurisdiction would issue someone a CCW permit that is good for life&#8230;after all, who is to say that your mental capacity hasn&#8217;t deteriorated due to age, illness or other circumstances since you got that permit 35 years ago?  Regardless of who the sheriff has &#8220;the hits&#8221; for, everyone should be required to renew their permit from time to time and demonstrate that they are still qualified to carry.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-9970">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9970" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9970"> http://www.facebook.com/dw75474                <span id="dsq-author-user-9970">Doyle Martin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9970" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9970" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Ok Alan. The choice will be up to the person.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-14338">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14338" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14338">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14338">Compromise Now</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14338" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14338" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Florida and Texas require a fingerprint search before a CCW s issued but Florida allows residents to also carry tasers, Combat Knives and Billy Clubs</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-14453">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14453" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14453">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14453">Paul</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14453" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14453" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Have you even read the US Constitution? When I am out and about and well heeled, my radar is tuned to a higher frequency, and I recognize that if I&#8217;m not under IMMINENT danger of grave bodily injury or death, its far better to retire and live to fight another day. Of course I&#8217;m old, have a couple of fractured teeth and fingers from my younger days, and have learned to tolerate and avoid morons when possible.<br /> So far as open carry, I do respect anyone&#8217;s right to strap on a blaster and go about their daily chores. Personally, I don&#8217;t care to draw that much attention to myself. I do, from time to time, carry openly, especially in our beautiful woods and forests. Sometimes, though, in foul weather, I cover my sidearm with a jacket. Strangely, at that moment, I must possess a license, as the sidearm is concealed. Pennsylvania is working hard to adopt Constitutional Carry, and to clarify Transportation of Firearms.<br /> Keep working on your Legislature in Texas. Open carry isn&#8217;t off the table so long as you keep fighting for it.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-14737">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14737" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14737">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14737">Pete C</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14737" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14737" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You sir, could not be more wrong. I also lived in New York, down in the city and I was there for 36 years. As an Auxiliary Sergeant with the NYPD I was actually refused a Premises/Target Permit because &#8220;of the risk that I might (MIGHT) carry my gun concealed while on duty&#8221;. Now let&#8217;s get this straight; I&#8217;m an Auxiliary Police Supervisor, uniform, shield, ID and radio, and Peace Officer registration to go with the training (although that status is denied by the brass at 1 Police Plaza) and I can&#8217;t get a license for a handgun because some paranoid moron in the licensing bureau fears that I MIGHT, MAYBE, POSSIBLY carry concealed a handgun while in my uniform and on duty. Aux P/Os cannot carry on duty even if they are peace officers in their regular jobs with permission to pack on their job. But here in Idaho, my Enhanced Permit (renewed every 5 years) is accepted in 34 states now as a CCW permit. How many states accept your &#8220;license for life&#8221; from New York? I&#8217;ll save you the trouble: just 20 states that choose to recognize NY State&#8217;s permit. And they all accept every state&#8217;s permit. Even Idaho. New York&#8217;s permit system and the accompanying psycho-babble justifying it is just excuse-ology meant to hamstring as many people as can be forbidden from actually owning any firearms at all. Pap, I say. Oh, I agree about the mentally ill and very young children, but some felons, SOME (not all) should have their rights returned to them due to the non-violent nature of their crimes. My own brother is one. For 40 years he&#8217;s been forbidden from owning or possessing firearms or projectile weapons of any kind or variety due to a stupid thing he did of a completely non-violent nature when he was 19. There is little rhyme or reason to this &#8220;system&#8221;. It&#8217;s time all the 50 states and all of the territories and commonwealths started recognizing each others permits and licenses, just as the Constitution says we all have to do as per Article IV, section 1 is to &#8220;respect the public acts, records and judicial proceedings of every other state&#8221;.  The Full Faith and Credit Clause is one of THE most important Articles of the Constitution because it sets the basic tone of the interrelationships between the &#8220;various states&#8221;. We ALL need to keep these things in mind. And come to Idaho; you&#8217;ll love it out here where the air is free and clear!!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-18837">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-18837" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-18837">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-18837">jaustin2008</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-18837" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-18837" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Yeah because new York people are so collected. Perfect example of someone that had no business having firearms and a non efficient background check.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-21650">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-21650" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-21650"> http://www.usacarry.com                <span id="dsq-author-user-21650">Damon</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-21650" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-21650" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Is your CCW Permit good in NYC?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-21732">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-21732" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-21732">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-21732">lefty</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-21732" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-21732" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I,m from MN and am surprized thwhen you mention a ccw for life. <div id="dsq-comment-header-22171" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22171">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22171">Christine Kaplan</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22171" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22171" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>That is utter bullshit.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-22446">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22446" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22446">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22446">tmaca</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22446" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22446" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>FALSE!!!  Most, in fact I believe all of them nowadays, run fingerprints through the FBI before issuing concealed carry permits.  This has been the case since at least the late 1990s.  NY, like many East Coast states (CT, DC, MA, MD, RI) just does not recognize permits from ANY other state, even ones that are as strict on checking as NY is.  For example, CT, which is not recognized by NY, and also does not recognize NY,  requires a permit from your local city police, who run the FBI fingerprint check, before you can even apply for a state permit.  The 2 states I have permits in now, Utah and Nevada, run the prints, and Nevada requires passing an all day handgun course and an actual shooting test.  NY just doesn&#8217;t like civilians having handguns (nor does CT).  Northeast states, in general, just don&#8217;t like citizens to be armed.  I NY I was literally laughed at in the early &#8217;70s when I asked to apply for a permit at the Schenectady PD, and in CT 3 years later the city PD said not to bother applying, they wouldn&#8217;t approve it, and a year after that I was a city cop, working for that very same PD.  There was obviously nothing wrong with me or my background.  Then I went myself to the state HQ in Wallingford to get a state permit  (In CT even a sworn law enforcement officer couldn&#8217;t legally carry outside his jurisdiction unless he had a state permit), and they said I didn&#8217;t have a good enough reason; I&#8217;d put &#8220;self defense&#8221; just to see what would happen, but they suddenly changed their mind when I showed them my badge and ID.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-22558">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22558" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22558">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22558">ed</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22558" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22558" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Pa also requires fingerprints, still no reciprocity.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-22671">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22671" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22671">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22671">NavyGunner</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22671" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22671" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Back in the day, convicted felons, mentally incompetent, and underage, were not considered citizens, merely residents. And only in upper New York State can you obtain a lifetime CCW Permit, or is it a&#8221;target/hunting&#8221; permit? In Idaho, I have a permit (the &#8220;Enhanced&#8221; CCW Permit) that only lasts for 5 years, but it&#8217;s good for concealed carry in 36 states! New York State is recognized in 29 states. And the only two states out here in the Northwestern US that do not recognize our permits are the only two states that recognize NO other state; they are California and Oregon. There are more states like mine, and New York has only recently received recognition for their permit from these other states. New York has been behind the eight ball for many years with these legal squabbles going on over there. And I say all these things as a native born New Yorker from Manhattan, aka New York County. The Original New York City. And having served there as an UNARMED Auxiliary Police Officer, I can tell you, Never Again. I&#8217;d rather move to one of the 5 states that now have Constitutional Carry. There&#8217;s one directly next door to you all over there; that&#8217;s Vermont. Since the days of the American Revolution, there has been no law concerning the carriage of any firearm, either openly or concealed; long gun or handgun. Maybe that is why Vermont is one of THE safest states in the Nation !!!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-23459">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23459" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23459">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23459">Rob Huckfeldt</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23459" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23459" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>If the convicted or mentally ill you speak of are so dangerous, why are they not locked up? Some slightly, others drastically.  You really need to know these differences from one state to another. Maybe not just passing through, but if you are relocating..absolutely.  An example is..The castle doctrine, some have some don&#8217;t, all are different. In NC you can NEVER use deadly force to protect property or animals period, in Texas, a neighbor can use deadly force to protect a neighbor&#8217;s property without the element of Immanent threat of death, serious bodily injury, or sexual assault.  Although I strongly agree with Texas and believe the B and E rate would drop if we all that that, try that in NC and the good guy goes to jail, or at least gets charged.  The list goes on.  Larry</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-14033">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14033" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14033">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14033">Hugh Jassol</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14033" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14033" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>because you can&#8217;t spell FELONY. If you go to court for something that requires you to give up some rights thusly losing your firearm rights so be it. But they should treat the CCW permit like a DL (don&#8217;t post holders in the newspaper or searchable on line). I am a ham operator also, and that is searchable (don&#8217;t even think about it <img src="http://www.usacarry.com/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_wink.gif" alt=";-)" class="wp-smiley" /> )</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-15743">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-15743" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-15743"> http://mom2giqm.wordpress.com/                <span id="dsq-author-user-15743">Anne-Marie</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-15743" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-15743" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Because each state is an autonomous nation state per the US Constitution. Despite what we&#8217;ve been told all of our lives, the US is not a &#8220;nation&#8221;, it is a Federal Union&#8230;a group of nation states for the common purposes of defense, security, and (later) finances&#8230;even though the Federal government has been usurping state&#8217;s rights since the 1790&#8217;s. That&#8217;s why laws vary from state to state. As inconvenient as it might seem, the more autonomy the better. It would be best if we were operating fully under state&#8217;s rights so that Floridians don&#8217;t have to conform to the idiocy of Californians and so forth.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-16511">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16511" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16511">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16511">robert perrotta</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16511" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16511" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>In most states that are reciprocity, say Utah to Ohio. If you have a Utah permit, there is no law that state you must transfer your Utah permit. In fact you can carry on it until it expires and then renew it if you would like. Ohio attorney generals agreement clearly states that they will honor states with similar requirements, those of which have been entered into a reciprocity agreement, as their own. So moving from one recipotory to another is not that big of a deal.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-16513">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16513" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16513">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16513">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16513" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16513" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>That is incorrect. If you are issued a resident permit in Utah, and then move out of state, your Utah permit is no longer valid since you are no longer a resident. It is also your responsibility to keep your information, such as address, up to date and correct with the issuing authority.</p> <p>Further, to get a Utah non-resident permit now, you would first have to get one from your new home state, Ohio in your example.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-16516">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16516" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16516">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16516">robert perrotta</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16516" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16516" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Hmm, well when I called the Attorney Generals Office, he said my Florida Non Resident CCW was sufficient to carry under Ohio law, I just assumed my analogy was correct. Moving from one reciprocity state to another, so Utahs would not suffice ohios? Simply because of the law change there?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-16517">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16517" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16517">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16517">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16517" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16517" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>If your Florida non-resident permit is valid then, yes, it is ok in Ohio as long as they recognize Florida permits, specifically non-resident ones in your case.</p> <p>In your example of moving to another state, your situation is dependent on the laws of the original issuing state, Utah in your example, to determine if said permit is still valid.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> If we go back to the founding of our &#8220;nation&#8221;, we were comprised of 13 individual States. &#8220;State&#8221; in 18th century speak is a country. The US Constitution was NOT a document creating one nation, but a compact agreed on by 13 separate nations/countries creating a&#8221;union of States&#8221; for a few specific, enumerated functions (common defense, etc).<br /> No matter how convenient a national reciprocity act would be, always be careful what you wish for. Every time we allow the Feds to &#8220;help&#8221; us, we give them license to intervene when it is not in our best interest (federal gun laws restricting rights).</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-10616">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-10616" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-10616">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-10616">Tommie</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-10616" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-10616" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Hay Bob, You are right on that, I agree with that for sure, If your a responsible person and safe with the pistol and obey all the laws, Safety is a must in the open or concealed carry, Its your right to carry if you got a clean record, There are a lot of persons who carry and shouldn&#8217;t, The state police in Michigan even say now that open carry is a  legal activity all it takes is some idiot to ruin it for evryone God bless</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-10652">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-10652" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-10652"> http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=655744678                <span id="dsq-author-user-10652">Brad Manzenberger</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-10652" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-10652" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You are right, and the Constitution mandates it. I think it stinks; I am an American, not just a Pennsylvanian, Washingtonian, Utahn, Vermonter, etc. It also means I end up paying hundreds of dollars a year to multiple states effectively to be in a FEDERAL database that does no more than document that I am law abiding and have been all my life.</p> <p>I also believe that the Constitution is my carry permit, so I resent being required to have to license my carry anyway! I don&#8217;t have to have a permit to conceal my smartphone/iPad (First Amendment) or my PGP or keys or remote clicker for the car/garage (Fourth Amendment). And bad people do bad things with those technologies as well. </p> <p>In my experience, radical anti-gun people are a) clueless about firearms and b) mentally immature: they have rejected mature tool use and adult self sufficiency in favor of&#8230;I&#8217;m not even sure what. I&#8217;ve never understood the projection that anti-RKBA/2A people have. BTW, I&#8217;m a liberal. My bigger concern is the POWERFUL anti-gun interests, and how they play on anti-gun liberals and make them dance like puppets.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-12958">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-12958" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-12958"> http://twitter.com/nNeufeld                <span id="dsq-author-user-12958">Nic Neufeld</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12958" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12958" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I would be inclined to agree with you&#8230;however because of our federal form of government, states have a certain amount (not enough, I would argue) of sovereignty. This is extremely important for our society. I would, however, like to see something like a coalition formed between a large number of states setting forth standards and creating a unified permitting system.</p> </div>         </div> So far as my being able to handle a firearm safely, and hit a target, that&#8217;s a PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY that weighs heavy on me. I don&#8217;t have any requirement for training, but I have taken more classes than you can shake a stick at since 1969, and I still practice and pick up pointers. Reliance on the Nanny State to establish some arbitrary &#8220;requirement&#8221; is foolish. Trusting the citizenry to perforate the proper parasite if necessary, with proficiency, is what Freedom is all about.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-17105">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-17105" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-17105">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-17105">Dan</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17105" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17105" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I agree Bob. That is a privilege given by the states.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" They are firearms and/or guns. It is not until it is used for protection that it should be labeled as a &#8221; weapon&#8221;. For example: a baseball bat is a tool used for sports. If it is used to hurt someone it has now become a weapon. Guns are used for hunting &amp; shooting competiions, etc. Calling it a weapon right from the satrt may be one of the reasons why some people are anti-gun to begin with. It just makes all guns/firearms sound like they are bad or evil without people ever seeing the good or justifiable reasons of carrying for self defense purposes. </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-5649">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5649" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5649">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5649">Phillip</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5649" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5649" class="dsq-comment-message"><p> Let&#8217;s call it what it is&#8230;..a weapon.  There is nothing inherently bad about weapons.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-6209">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6209" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6209">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6209">StoutCortez</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6209" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6209" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I am a certified NRA instructor.  That is all.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-5620">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5620" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5620">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5620">GUNSMOAK</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5620" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5620" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Maybe I do not understand.  Isn&#8217;t the Constitution of the united States of America a document that curtails the power that WE have granted to the Federal government?  Does not the 2nd Amendment to that Federal Constitution list a Right specifically that should NOT BE INFRINGED by any law promulgated by a Federal body?<br /> Have not States reserved the power to regulate whatever they please w/in their State.<br /> If your State does not accept my Driver License, I will simply drive around your State.  That&#8217;s the way it is meant to be by the founding dreamers that so miraculously penned the dream that became our REPUBLIC.  All one needs is to spend a few moments a day in reading to understand the precepts.  I suggest the original Constitution, and a daily dose of Federalist Papers.</p> <p>GUNSMOAK </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-6206">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6206" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6206">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6206">StoutCortez</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6206" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6206" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Right. But the anti-gun crowd has long argued that while nine amendments guarantee or enumerate the rights of the people, the Second Amendment guarantees a right to the government.</p> <p>Sound nuts? Yes, it IS nuts.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-5631">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5631" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5631">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5631">Rambler7074</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5631" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5631" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I am a firm believer of the 2nd amendment, that unless you have been found unfit to qualify you are born as an American with that right, without a license fee and it should be any where in America and<br /> or their territory, unless you have been found abusive to that right.  Jim from Indiana</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-5637">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5637" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5637">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5637">Sripantwsk</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5637" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5637" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>can I tranfer my CCW from Washington states to FL? They shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than ten<br /> years, or both; and if death results from the acts committed in<br /> violation of this section&#8221;<br /> U.S. Code, Title 18, Section 242;<br /> &#8220;Whoever, under color of any law, statute, ordinance, regulation, or<br /> custom, willfully subjects any person in any State, Territory,<br /> Commonwealth, Possession, or District to the deprivation of any rights,<br /> privileges, or immunities secured or protected by the Constitution or<br /> laws of the United States&#8230;. shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than one year, or<br />  both; and if bodily injury results from the acts committed in violation<br />  of this section or if such acts include the use, attempted use, or<br /> threatened use of a dangerous weapon, explosives, or fire, shall be<br /> fined under this title or imprisoned not more than ten years, or both;<br /> and if death results from the acts committed in violation of this<br /> section or if such acts include kidnapping or an attempt to kidnap,<br /> aggravated sexual abuse, or an attempt to commit aggravated sexual<br /> abuse, or an attempt to kill, shall be fined under this title, or<br /> imprisoned for any term of years or for life, or both, or may be<br /> sentenced to death.&#8221;</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-5731">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5731" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5731">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5731">Mike from Florida</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5731" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5731" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I think states would save a lot of money if they just got rid of the separate ID system and charged the fees as an endorsement to drivers licenses. rule of thumb:  If you won&#8217;t honor my CCW, I won&#8217;t visit your state.  On the rare occasion I have to travel through a state that won&#8217;t honor my permit, (Illinois occosionally), I make sure my service tank in the back of the truck is full of fuel, and my thermos is topped off.  You won&#8217;t get a penny of mine.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li Depending on what county you live in it takes anywhere from 2 &#8211; 12 months to get your permit and that&#8217;s after you have already completed the following:<br /> 1. attended a safety class.<br /> 2. Had 3 non family member county residents fill out a form and had it notorized in order to vouch for your character.<br /> 3. Given a full set of finger prints,<br /> 4. Been cleared by the FBI<br /> 5. Been cleared by the State Mental Health Department<br /> 6. Paid a couple hundred dollars for the permit and safety class.<br /> 7. Purchased a firearm. (which most shops make you pay for in full even though your not permitted to even touch it or hold it in your hand prior to purchasing it! Of course you have to wait the 2 &#8211; 12 months for your permit to come in before you can pick it up from the store)<br /> 8. Had an interview with the Sherrifs department and provided a letter stating why you are applying for a pistol license.</p> <p>It took 4 months when I applied for mine a few years ago. I know a few people that waited over a year to get their permits. Think about that for a minute, It takes all this time just to purchase a pistol or revolver whether you intend to carry it or not! Just to purchase a gun to keep in your home in order to protect your family. I don&#8217;t think thats what our founding fathers had in mind when they wrote the 2nd amendment.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-5979">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-5979" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-5979">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-5979">shonsay efffyoo</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-5979" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-5979" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>the people can keep not the non peeples like niggers or non land owners or your mom and dad cuz YOO 4git tobvote  r just by a fn gun and lode it to kill </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-6005">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6005" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6005">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6005">Danbfree</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6005" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6005" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>WTF? So if you live in Alabama and have an Arizona permit (nonresident, obviously), you&#8217;re good in Ohio. But if you live in Ohio, an Arizona permit won&#8217;t cover you. You have to have an Ohio permit, regardless of how many permits you have that Ohio honors.</p> <p>Wisconsin is another state that requires a Wisconsin permit for its residents.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-6178">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6178" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6178"> http://pulse.yahoo.com/_VYKEPM2YQAVBAGNRTN23PSJYJU                <span id="dsq-author-user-6178">WOP2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6178" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6178" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I&#8217;ve seen a lot of comments on this board calling for either State or Federally mandated training for those with a License to Carry. means that no one can see, and you don&#8217;t let anyone know, that you&#8217;re carrying.  This means no outline&#8230; mild bulges are somewhat common and after you start concealed carrying you may notice a lot more people with similar bulges that could be firearms.  If you&#8217;re license to concealed carry in your state, and go into Vermont you may continue to consealed carry in Vermont (is the short answer).</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-6252">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6252" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6252">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6252">Areyouforreal2 Ww</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6252" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6252" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>God Bless Texas.               <span id="dsq-author-user-6404">Larry Rhude</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6404" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6404" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>All of you who are complaining about the &#8220;Right to Carry&#8221; issues should, if you have not already done so, read USA Carry&#8217;s piece on Senate bill S2188. It is a bill to require every state that has a right to carry provision, either by permit or not, to honor every other state&#8217;s permit to carry.  It is the companion to the bill passed in the house that says just that.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-6405">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6405" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6405">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6405">Larry Rhude</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6405" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6405" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I failed to mention the most important comment. Consequently, an individual state&#8217;s laws trump all others. You need to get on the website, and KNOW THE LAW in every State you&#8217;ll be travelling through. If you are going through South Carolina and Maryland, for example, your guns are O.K. in transit because under Federal law you are going to a State where it is lawful for you to carry, i.e. Kentucky. In both SC and MD, though, you need to stop, unload your gun, lock it and the ammo in separate containers not accessible to the drivers and passengers, and drive straight through.<br />  <br /> I guarantee you that the laws in every State you drive through are similar, but they are not the same, and the burden is on YOU to know the laws in every State you visit. This will remain the same even if HR 822 and S 2213 become the law of the land. So far as I can see, with the exception of Federal laws regarding interstate transportation of firearms, State law will always pre-empt the laws in the State that issued you your License to Carry Firearms, or CCW, or whatever name they give it.  </p> <p>THIS MESSAGE WAS ACTUALLY FOR HOLONAI, TRAVELING TO KENTUCKY. When I visit relatives in Chicago, I&#8217;m well heeled. If I get caught, I guess I&#8217;m going to jail.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-6605">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6605" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6605">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6605">Holanoi</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6605" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6605" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I will be travelling to KY and I would like to take one of my weapons with me for protection and I do not want to break any law or rules. Does anybody knows? </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-6606">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6606" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6606">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6606">Holanoi</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6606" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6606" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I have a permit from Florida; do the states that accept my permit have the same regulations? I will be travelling to KY and I would like to take one of my weapons with me for protection and I do not want to break any law or rules. Does anybody know? </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-6630">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6630" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6630"> http://pulse.yahoo.com/_VYKEPM2YQAVBAGNRTN23PSJYJU                <span id="dsq-author-user-6630">WOP2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6630" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6630" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>RKBA is indeed a States&#8217; Rights issue, contrary to what the politicos in D.C. would tell you. Consequently, an individual state&#8217;s laws trump all others. You need to get on the website, and KNOW THE LAW in every State you&#8217;ll be travelling through. If you are going through South Carolina and Maryland, for example, your guns are O.K. in transit because under Federal law you are going to a State where it is lawful for you to carry, i.e. Kentucky. In both SC and MD, though, you need to stop, unload your gun, lock it and the ammo in separate containers not accessible to the drivers and passengers, and drive straight through. </p> <p>I guarantee you that the laws in every State you drive through are similar, but they are not the same, and the burden is on YOU to know the laws in every State you visit. This will remain the same even if HR 822 and S 2213 become the law of the land. So far as I can see, with the exception of Federal laws regarding interstate transportation of firearms, State law will always pre-empt the laws in the State that issued you your License to Carry Firearms, or CCW, or whatever name they give it</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-6629">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6629" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6629"> http://pulse.yahoo.com/_VYKEPM2YQAVBAGNRTN23PSJYJU                <span id="dsq-author-user-6629">WOP2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6629" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6629" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>RKBA is indeed a States&#8217; Rights issue, contrary to what the politicos in D.C. would tell you. Consequently, an individual state&#8217;s laws trump all others. You need to get on the website, and KNOW THE LAW in every State you&#8217;ll be travelling through. If you are going through South Carolina and Maryland, for example, your guns are O.K. in transit because under Federal law you are going to a State where it is lawful for you to carry, i.e. Kentucky. In both SC and MD, though, you need to stop, unload your gun, lock it and the ammo in separate containers not accessible to the drivers and passengers, and drive straight through.<br />  <br /> I guarantee you that the laws in every State you drive through are similar, but they are not the same, and the burden is on YOU to know the laws in every State you visit. This will remain the same even if HR 822 and S 2213 become the law of the land. So far as I can see, with the exception of Federal laws regarding interstate transportation of firearms, State law will always pre-empt the laws in the State that issued you your License to Carry Firearms, or CCW, or whatever name they give it.  </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-6662">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6662" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6662">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6662">Ravenfire77</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6662" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6662" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I am fortunate enough to live in Wyoming.  </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-6668">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6668" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6668">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6668">Paul</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6668" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6668" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>any idea how long it takes to get the utah permit?</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-6686">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6686" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6686"> http://pulse.yahoo.com/_VYKEPM2YQAVBAGNRTN23PSJYJU                <span id="dsq-author-user-6686">WOP2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6686" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6686" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Mine took a total of about 3 weeks, but there is no guarantee your&#8217;s will be that quick. You MUST take a course of instruction from a Utah certified instructor, submit a fingerprint card, undergo an FBI and Utah background check, AND pass a short test at the end of the one day course. Utah is tough on offenders, too, and darned near anything can get your Utah &#8220;permit&#8221; to get yanked. </p> <p>One other thing to bear in mind, right to carry remains a State&#8217;s Rights issue. If you intend to use your Utah permit to travel to states that your home state has no reciprocity with, its your responsibility to know the laws in each state. You can get busted in Ohio by taking a loaded magazine into a gun free zone, as a loaded magazine in Ohio is considered a firearm. Hey&#8211;you can&#8217;t make that stuff up!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## id="dsq-comment-6897">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6897" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6897">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6897">guest</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6897" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6897" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I am very Conservative myself, but having lived in Maine for years this isn&#8217;t always the liberal vs conservative issue the media would have you believe.   Hell, Vermont is so liberal they have a socialist in Congress, yet the most liberal gun laws in country&#8230;..there virtually are no gun laws.   We in Maine had to RINOs as Senators and everyone else used to be not just Democratic but over the top liberal.   Thank fully  that took a incredible change last election cycle.  Yet Maine is a shall issue and open carry state.    Don&#8217;t fall for the media crap that trys to frame arguement as liberal vs conservative on this specific issue.    I would agree on city (liberal) verse country&#8230;..</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd I am of the opinion a state should only reciprocate with those who do the same. </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-6922">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-6922" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-6922">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-6922">JTEM</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-6922" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-6922" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I disagree as this is impinging still further on our Second Amendmentt rights. A gun is only dangerous in the hands of a dangerous or careless person. If his buddy is trainable, he should be trained and allowed his right under the second amendment. If he is a liability to others, perhaps you&#8217;d want to be his neighbor.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-8200">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-8200" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-8200">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-8200">Adventurer</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-8200" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-8200" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Indiana has a license to carry which requires no classroom instruction whatsoever. While I do have years of training, that may not assuage fears in the minds of the anti gun crowd. I like the National Reciprocity with maybe standardized gun training requirements.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-8335">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-8335" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-8335">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-8335">Alonzo</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-8335" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-8335" class="dsq-comment-message"><p> I&#8217;m also for National Reciprocity. Training is required for police, so we should be no different.  The question is how much.  NV has an 8 hour training requirement, but fewer states accept NV CCW than FL CCW&#8230;why.  Just saying, Adventurer is right, let&#8217;s standardize the training.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-8978">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-8978" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-8978">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-8978">cvmagreek</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-8978" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-8978" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You would also think that in order to even qualify to get the permit, you cannot have any felony or misdemeanor convictions or any domestic violence or a number of other things unlawful against you! In other words, you a law abiding citizen who wants a responsible right to your protection from criminals!!!!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-8576">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-8576" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-8576">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-8576">DennisRH</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-8576" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-8576" class="dsq-comment-message"><p> The only problem with national reciprocity is involving the feds. Article IV section I states &#8221; Full Faith and Credit shall be given in each State to the public Acts, Records, and judicial Proceedings of every other State. .&#8221; This is why you can drive in all states with your residential drivers license and why you don&#8217;t have to get married again when you move to another state. Simple as that. </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-8967">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-8967" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-8967">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-8967">caledurago</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-8967" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-8967" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Steve that is absolutly correct, you go after the violator.  </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-7978">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-7978" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-comment-header-7987" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-7987">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-7987">Dave</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-7987" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-7987" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>My wife woke me up one night saying &#8220;some one is in the hallway&#8221; Sure enough I heard him too and he was not even trying to be quiet. I jumped up and swung the bedroom door open and walked hard into the barrel of 12 guage shotgun jamed in to my chest.<br /> I imediatly grabbed the barrel and forced it upward, I first tried to wrestle the gun off the intruder but then remembered what my dad had told me that he had learned in the war. that was that if I was ever in this kind of situation that I should go after the man not the weapon. The man will be defending the wepon with his life because if he knows that if you get it off him he is a dead man. So since he is defending it with his life, then it is an easy think to take;his life that is.<br /> I held the barrel away from me and my wife with one hand as he had a death grip on it with both his hands, with my free hand I was able to beat him until he lost enough conciousness to stand, I then remembered the second thing he told me, that was if the man goes down go down with him, otherwise he will still have the gun and you will now be at the wrong end of it, stay closer than the barrel length.<br /> So I did, and got the gun off him, I then put the gun in the hall behind me, and started fighting him and forcing him down the hallway to the stairs where I through him and he cleared all the steps and landed in a ball on the floor. unconcious I loaded him into the back of my truck and dropped him off at the police station. Then went home and back to bed.<br /> This all took time, a good having a good handgun would have made much shorter work of it and I could have got back to bed sooner:)</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-10305">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-10305" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-10305">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-10305">FreedomForever</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-10305" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-10305" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You did better than me, I wouldve been cleaning red crap off the walls for a week. Justice would have been served if he was in my house!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-8050">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-8050" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-8050">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-8050">Deez</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-8050" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-8050" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Anyone else notice the states with the highest crime rates have the strictest gun laws?  Funny how that works</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-8143">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-8143" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-8143"> http://pulse.yahoo.com/_F5DZOCHDHVY7SE226XYLN4SO4E                <span id="dsq-author-user-8143">CT</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-8143" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-8143" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Please update the USA Carry map.
