PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY. The instant you encourage the Government, be it local, state, or Federal, to establish an approved training course, you create another layer of the nanny state. I like what Pennsylvania, my home state, does. You apply, you get your License to Carry a Firearm, and you carry. There is an expectation that you will get as much training as you can afford. Indeed, PA is now considering HB 2176, Constitutional Carry, which would provide for any person not otherwise prohibited, the right to carry concealed without any interference from Harrisburg. I carry, I&#8217;m not only trained, but I practice, and no-one said I had to do so. </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-8724">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-8724" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-8724">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-8724">jerrykregle</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-8724" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-8724" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I really wish whorehouse Harry would get the Concealed Weapon Permit reciprocity<br /> bill through the senate.<br />   once that passes and becomes law   only 1 state Illinois you would not be able to carry<br /> because they do not have ANY CWP at all<br /> then you will see Bloomberg in NY and Governor Moonbeam in the PRC bring a federal<br /> lawsuit </p> <p> I have always taken an issue with this  I your drivers license and your marriage certificate<br /> is backed by the full faith and credit clause in the constitution WHY isn&#8217;t a constitutional right guaranteed too<br /> I also believe your fishing and hunting  license should have the same full faith and credit too </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-8736">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-8736" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-8736">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-8736">MJB</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-8736" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-8736" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Didnt Texas recently pass a law that they would honor ALL states&#8217; permits? I would like to know which states you are allowed to carry your pistol in with a chambered round. If anyone could help me out with that info I would appreciate it. Thanks Charles</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-9282">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9282" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9282">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9282">WOP 2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9282" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9282" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Charles:<br /> Please do not take this as a derogatory comment. A gun is considered to be loaded, in the case of a pistol, in practically 100% of the United States if a loaded magazine is inserted into the magazine well. Whether you have chambered a round is immaterial. This brings me to the more important question. Do you intend to carry a semi-automatic pistol without a live round in the chamber? If so, please attend a course of instruction specific to your firearm, get loads of practice, and carry with a round chambered. An empty chamber simply turns your semi-auto pistol into a brick. Some will say that it takes but a second to rack the slide. In a panic situation, you&#8217;ll point your blaster, pull the trigger, and when that sickening &#8220;click&#8221; instead of &#8220;boom&#8221; is heard, you&#8217;re already a dead man. Again, I&#8217;m not being critical, just offering some advice I&#8217;ve picked up in over 40 years of concealed and open carry.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-9285">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9285" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9285">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9285">Slash</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9285" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9285" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>First I do not take offense at all, you answered my question, thank you. I had just heard from a couple friends that you could not carry with one in the chamber in some states because it was illegal.  I just purchased an FN 5.7  a couple of months ago and I plan on practicing with it extensively as soon as my ammo I ordered arrives.  I also agree with you 100% that you should always have one in the chamber or your weapon is useless.  Once again thank you for taking the time to respond to my question.  I greatly appreciate it.  You and yours stay safe.   Charles </p> <p>________________________________</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-9303">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9303" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9303">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9303">Paul</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9303" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9303" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>does Iowa and Minnesota recognize Kansas CC </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-9319">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9319" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9319">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9319">joe</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9319" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9319" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>could someone please explain what the scientologists were doing carrying handguns in nyc ?????? ny does not recognize any  states permits?????  just curious how mayor bloomburd didnt find out </p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-9327">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9327" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9327">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9327">Pathfinder 101</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9327" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9327" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>After reading some of the posts,some of you guys need a life.  I have a right to keep and bear arms. Some will state that it&#8217;s fair, some that it&#8217;s not.  I would tend to agree with AlanBuffloNY in that their are some states which issue CCW to some just for having a pulse.  C&#8217;mon folks, we know that many felons (unless their rights have been restored), should NOT be carrying a weapon, period.  That&#8217;s up to the judge.  And you invariably have to have a judge, or the local sheriff sign your permit.  So some of you want Rufus from the &#8216;hood, who knocked off a liquor store to carry?  I don&#8217;t think so.  But the fool who did a non-violent crime MAY get his rights restored if the judge accepts his basis for restoration.  Additionally, those who are mentally ill and can&#8217;t make good judgement calls shouldn&#8217;t have them either.  Frankly, some of the complainers may fit into either category, so sorry Charlie, you shouldn&#8217;t be carrying, and netiher should your inbred cousins.  We&#8217;re not making this the old West; and if we did, then lets bring back vigilante hanging so we can put your azz up in the nearest tree when you misuse your weapons.<br /> One thing I believe we can all agree upon:  make the standards for CCW permit the SAME all over this nation, and then allow those elible to carry in support of our 2nd Amendment.  But the criteria for carrying must be consistent, and troublemakers should not be allowed to carry.  Perhaps an IQ test would be in order, that&#8217;s clear up much of this nonsense.<br /> U.S. Army retired,<br /> 29 years, Special Forces</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-9839">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9839" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9839"> http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100003300316146                <span id="dsq-author-user-9839">Benyamin Tover</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9839" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9839" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>And for those tough talkin&#8217; pizzants who think they&#8217;re tough, I served in 3 wars and actually have had to use rifle, pistol and machine gun in combat. Mandatory training sucks, because in some states  (Utah, for example), you&#8217;re never required to fire a shot, just pass a written test. Including military police service, I&#8217;ve drawn my weapon 5 times since 1969, never having to have fired a shot. Thanks to God for that. What you will do if faced with a lethal force encounter is precisely what you have trained yourself to do. Hesitation will get you killed. I practice frequently from different positions, with pistol, rifle and shotgun, and can honestly say that while I think I&#8217;m prepared, I should, as a responsible firearms owner and concealed carry person, practice even more. The gun doesn&#8217;t make you tough. Mental, physical, and repetitive training make you tough. Sometimes a broken nose or a busted jaw administered by a crushing right cross is as effective as a .45. I think, Ben, that&#8217;s what you&#8217;re saying, and I agree with you.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-9870">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-9870" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-9870">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-9870">mpireone</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-9870" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-9870" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>In any case, it&#8217;s a privilege to even own firearms, let alone being a concealed carry license holder. infringed.<br /> As ratified by the States and authenticated by Thomas Jefferson, Secretary of State:<br /> A well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the PEOPLE to KEEP and BEAR arms shall not be infringedACCORDING TO BILL OF RIGHTSDefinition of KEEPtransitive verb4 a: to retain in one&#8217;s possession or powerDefinition of BEARtransitive verb1 a: to move while holding up and supporting (something)   b: to be equipped or furnished with (something)   c: behave, conduct    d: to have as a feature or characteristic    e: to give as testimony    f: to have as an identification    g: to hold in the mind or emotions    h: disseminate   i: lead, escort   j: render, give ACCORDING TO MERRIAM-WEBSTER.COM</p> </div>         </div>     <ul I believe that correct and complete information would be that Oregon is shall-issue for residents and may-issue for residents of the four contiguous states, that is, Idaho, California, Washington and Nevada.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-10829">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-10829" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-10829">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-10829">Freethinker01</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-10829" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-10829" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Thank you for taking the time to keep this updated. They do not make you feel like you are doing wrong by owning/carrying a gun.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-10850">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-10850" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-10850">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-10850">COP1612</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-10850" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-10850" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I would like to see a national effort to put pressure on our electorate to enact legislation similar to Public Law 108-277 (which I currently enjoy), which would afford all citizens to exercise their 2nd amendment right is they so choose, regardless of state, local laws to the contrary.  The 2nd Amendment is in the &#8220;United States&#8221; constitution, meaning it should apply to all states equally, similar to the &#8220;Miranda Ruling&#8221; and the 5th Amendment protection which applies equally to all states.  I could give more examples of how rules of the constitution apply equally to all states.  We need to attack this problem as a constitutional problem and not as individual state problems.  The way I read the constitution, concealed or open carry should be not be infringed by any state, I read no education or training requirement.  In Illinois, Bill of Rights,Article I, Sec. 22 reads: Right to Arms &#8211; Subject only to the police power, the right of the individual citizen to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed, Artical XII Militia, Sec. 1, membership; reads- The state militia consists of all able-bodied persons residing in the state except those exempted by law.  I don&#8217;t know why Illinois lawyers can&#8217;t when guns rights cases with these two rights in the Illinois constitution.  We gun owners should stop fighting 50 separate battles to secure our 2nd Amendment rights, we should fight one with the United States government at any and all levels until the government recognizes the 2nd Amendment does apply equally to all citizens in all states equally.  </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-10853">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-10853" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-10853">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-10853">Bhdaugh</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-10853" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-10853" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I&#8217;m currently trying to push this as well.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-10876">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-10876" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-10876">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-10876">JAY C.</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-10876" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-10876" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I&#8217;m ready brother! Did my own analysis; think I figured it out&#8230; the 5 best states to get non-resident permits in, roughly in order, strictly from a carry-in-most-places perspective, are:  ND, FL, UT, AZ, and TX.  Some oddities I found in these &#8230;.  Among these 5 best for NR permits:  (1) Only UT, ND, and FL will allow carry in WA, (2) Only ND, FL, and TX will allow carry in NM, (3) Only UT does NOT allow carry in KS, (4) Only UT and TX allow carry in MN, (5) Only FL allows carry in FL!!!, (6)  Only AZ allows carry in NV, and (7) Only UT, ND, and AZ allow carry in WI.  On all the rest of the states, they&#8217;re the same, at least with respect to any state I&#8217;d ever want to visit.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-11608">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-11608" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-11608"> http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=722136046                <span id="dsq-author-user-11608">Daniel Stoner</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-11608" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-11608" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Actually now I&#8217;d rank them:  (1) ND, (2) UT, (3) AZ, (4) TX, and (5) FL .. again, this is only taking into account where all you can carry, and nothing else (cost, wait, headache, etc.).  UT, AZ, and TX are a virtual tie in the middle 3, with ND the clear winner, and FL the clear last place among the top 5.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-11609">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-11609" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-11609"> http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=722136046                <span id="dsq-author-user-11609">Daniel Stoner</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-11609" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-11609" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>If you want to go to as many states as possible, and are willing to get TWO NR permits (but only two), the best one-two punch combos are, roughly in order:  (1) UT plus FL &#8211; Lets you go anyplace that you&#8217;re capable of going (with NR permits), EXCEPT NV, (2)  ND plus AZ &#8211; Lets you go anyplace that you&#8217;re capable of going, EXCEPT MN or FL (unacceptable to me because I want to visit northern MN to go to the public lands there), (3) ND plus TX &#8211; Lets you go anyplace that you&#8217;re capable of going, EXCEPT NV or FL, and (4) UT plus AZ &#8211; Lets you go anyplace that you&#8217;re capable of going, EXCEPT NM or FL, and (5)  ND plus FL &#8211; Lets you go anyplace that you&#8217;re capable of going, EXCEPT NV or MN.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-11610">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-11610" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-11610"> http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=722136046                <span id="dsq-author-user-11610">Daniel Stoner</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-11610" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-11610" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>The best triple-state combo, if you&#8217;re willing to get three different ones, is clearly the sole winner of:   UT plus FL plus AZ .  This combo lets you go anywhere / everywhere that you&#8217;re capable of going with NR permits only, including WA, NM, KS, MN, FL, NV, WI, UT, AZ, TX, ND, and many others &#8211; but of course NOT in the really stingy states for some reason, like CO, SC, MI, ME, NH, and other places that you might think would.  There is no need to ever get 4 or more NR shall-issue permits, near as I can tell.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-11611">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-11611" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-11611"> http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=722136046                <span id="dsq-author-user-11611">Daniel Stoner</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-11611" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-11611" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I&#8217;m not going to get a Florida on principle &#8211; I don&#8217;t want to give my money to a state that is that stingy, so bottom line, for me, it&#8217;s a tossup between ND plus TX, or UT plus AZ.  If I don&#8217;t mind being disarmed in NV, and want to go armed in NM, then I should get ND plus TX.  If I don&#8217;t mind being disarmed in NM, and want to go armed in NV, then I should get UT plus AZ. And as such i believe in the right to defend myself, my family, and my way of life from all threats foreign and domestic.  yea i have a permit, but i don&#8217;t agree that i should have to have it, and in the state i live in i don&#8217;t have to have it but i got it for the reciprocity in 38 of the 48 lower states. and as an armed citizen i believe i have an obligation to carry every day and i do. i also believe that there will come a time when we will have to defend ourselves from ourselves, if that makes any sense.  think about this for a second, you and your family are walking down some street and your confronted by a man with a gun but you don&#8217;t believe that law abiding citizens should carry guns because the law will protect you, so you don&#8217;t have a gun or carry a gun, so the man grabs your child and demands your cash and such and you give it to him in hopes to save your child from harm. and what does this piece of slime do but shoot your child anyway because the child is of no use to him anymore and neither are you. so he continues to slaughter you and your family because he knows that you will not or can not defend yourself.now same situation except a group of law biding people pass by but they are concealed carry people and they see what is happening and do their duty draw the weapons they have and now the piece of slime must deal with being out gunned and because you also carry you are able to show that he will not get off so easy because you have drawn your weapon and stepped in front of your child to protect the child . i am just saying crimanals will have guns no matter what the law says, shouldnt you be able to protect your self? think about it in this situation where was the law when you needed them, they will show up after the child and possibly yourself and your family have been injured or worse killed, what help are they then.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-11720">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-11720" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-11720">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-11720">Johnny Alessi</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-11720" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-11720" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I once watched a man get beat to death by another mans bare hands. If that guy who died had a gun on him and he lived in Florida he might still be alive. That&#8217;s why I live in Florida and carry everyday everywhere. I carry a gun when I&#8217;m in my pajamas at home that&#8217;s how ready you have to be.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-11738">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-11738" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-11738">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-11738">Josh</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-11738" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-11738" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Virginia offers online test for $24.99 awesome right</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-11739">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-11739" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-11739">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-11739">Dakota in VA</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-11739" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-11739" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I have read a number of postings here and I’d like to add my two cents… There are those who like/love guns and those who dislike/hate guns.  And there is nothing wrong with<br /> that.  The issue is just as much about respect as it is about rights.  Respect as in, respecting other people’s views. Everyone is entitled to their views and just because they don’t agree with your view doesn’t make them a bad person or a non-American. </p> <p>I am a bleeding-heart liberal, but I carry a Sig.  But I also respect those who are anti gun. </p> <p>I think anyone who supports gun ownership and calls those who are opposed to guns any kind of names or calls them unpatriotic is doing a great disservice to the cause.  It would be far better for the cause to inform and educate the non-believers if you will, than point a finger at them and call them names with more than a hint of disdain in your voice.  You will never convert someone if you start the conversation calling them names simply because they have a different option than yours.  It doesn’t make them any less American. </p> <p>Who knows, maybe one day you will come to the aid of someone and the fact that you were in a position to help or save them might be enough to convert them… and you didn’t even have to call them a name.   If you believe it’s our constitutional right to bears arms, than you should equally believe it’s our right not to.   It’s a matter of choice and nothing could be more American.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-11740">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-11740" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-11740"> http://www.facebook.com/people/Agnon-Mema/100000001379385                <span id="dsq-author-user-11740">Agnon Mema</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-11740" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-11740" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I live in Minnesota, and my permit is not honored in very few of the uber-pro-2nd Amendment open-carry states&#8230;..</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-11750">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-11750" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-11750">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-11750">nopermitneeded</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-11750" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-11750" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>If law abiding citizens are not allowed to carry then only the criminals and the police who are so short staffed, underpaid, and overworked wil be carrying and we cannot defend ourselves. state and kill or injure an innocent bystander by missing your target, firearm misfire, or over penetration it is still your fault and will be prosecuted with manslaughter and or sued by said bystander&#8217;s family. it is better to find the state that has the most requirements and qualifiers to obtain the ccw and learn as much as you can about firearm law, firearm usage, and firearm In an odd twist, WI honors VA nonresident permits but not VA resident permits. It&#8217;s a shame how regular civilians have to suffer because of the ones doing the killing.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-12298">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-12298" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-12298">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-12298">bb</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12298" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12298" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>interstates should be exempt.. it&#8217;s such a pain in the butt trying to plan a trip home for the holidays and having to map your route around these stupid reciprocity agreements..  a 10 mile stretch through maryland will cost me and extra 50 miles just to avoid that liberal lunacy&#8230;</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-12318">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-12318" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-12318">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-12318">Edward</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12318" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12318" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I click on Wisconsin for resident ccw&#8230;states listed as not honoring include Wisconsin???</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-12340">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-12340" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-12340">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-12340">Ed</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12340" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12340" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>This needs to be updated. That said, the NFA of 1934 put serious restrictions on civilian ownership of machine guns and submachine guns. While I don&#8217;t think its necessary to have an M-2 quad mount  at your disposal to repel home invaders, I&#8217;ll take an AR platform rifle, semi-automatic,  in 5.56 NATO anytime as an adequate firearm to defend the home, or the driveway, or the immediate field of fire outside my residence.<br /> I do agree that a hand cannon is a convenient home protection firearm, and I have one at my bedside. It is not. It is &#8220;Shall Issue&#8221; only for residents &amp; property owners. Is is &#8220;May Issue&#8221; for non-residents of bordering states. &#8220;Won&#8217;t Issue&#8221; to other states.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-12602">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-12602" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-12602">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-12602">dosequis</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12602" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12602" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Rhode Island is a May Issue state. The basic permit allows you to carry most common places except anywhere alcohol is served or sold as a primary source of income, schools, federal bldgs, law enforcement centers, etc.  The Enhanced CCW, however, allows you to carry anywhere except a courtroom where a judge is on the bench, law enforcement centers, and federal bldgs.  The difference is that the enhanced CCW requires classroom training and range qualification.  Both require fingerprints and background checks.  This, to me, makes perfect sense and they have to be renewed every 5 years, including the class/range for the ECCW.  Logic is a funny thing&#8230;ain&#8217;t it?  It would make more sense to have better reciprocity or a uniform CCW process nationwide.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-12704">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-12704" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-12704">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-12704">KG</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12704" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12704" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Problem is that some states will issue a CWP to someone that has never picked up a gun or seen one up close, much less had any meaningful training.  That presents a danger to everyone.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-12706">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-12706" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-12706">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-12706">WOP 2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12706" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12706" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>This is where PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY kicks in. Do you want a Nanny State dictating what level of training and familiarity with your firearm you must have, or would you rather, as a responsible firearms owner, seek as much training as you can afford? It is incumbent upon any person who purchases any potentially dangerous item (chain saw, power mower, power saw) to insure that they safely and proficiently operate the item, and insure that children, and other adults, do not have unfettered access to the item.  I think any clear thinker can figure that out. State mandated training associated with the purchase of a gun can be capriciously changed at any time to make it more difficult or nearly impossible to buy, or to carry, a firearm for self defense. I mean, really, how much did you know about the destructive power of a chain saw the first time you bought it? Personal responsibility that accompanies each of our rights! What a concept.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-12707">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-12707" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-12707">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-12707">solodrums09</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-12707" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-12707" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I am kind of curious as to who&#8217;s, which state&#8217;s permit is accpted in more &#8220;other ststes&#8221; than anyone elses permit and why? (see note at end of this post)  If any portion of the Bill of Rights can be ignored, then so can any other. Only until the 1st Amendment right to freedom of speech is censored, will we see emphasis on preserving the entirety of the Bill of Rights. </p> <p>Firearms freedom legislation and federal gun laws nullification<br /> Starting in 2012, in response to a threat of law made through executive orders by President Obama, more than a dozen states around the US began proposing legislation that would &#8220;&#8230;declare that any firearms made and retained in-state are beyond the authority of Congress under its constitutional power to regulate commerce among the states&#8221;. The legislation would require that the firearm be prominently marked as being &#8220;Made in {name of state}&#8221; and further prohibit federal regulation solely on the basis that &#8220;basic materials&#8221; and &#8220;generic and insignificant parts&#8221; of the firearm may have their origins from outside the state.</p> <p>Through 2010, resolutions have been introduced in the legislatures of 27 states that would nullify federal authority over such local firearms. The legislation passed in Montana and Tennessee in 2009 and in Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, South Dakota, Utah, and Wyoming the following year.[12] South Carolina has taken the issue one step further: in 2010 a bill was introduced which would effectively nullify all gun registration laws within the state.[13]</p> <p>Texas has prefiled[14] and West Virginia has filed[15] similar legislation for the current 2011 legislative session.</p> <p>Reciprocity<br /> Many jurisdictions have established arrangements where they recognize or honor permits or licenses issued by other jurisdictions with comparable standards, for instance in regard to marriage or driver&#8217;s licenses. This is known as Reciprocity and is based on U.S. Constitution &#8220;full faith and credit&#8221; provision.[39] Due to the nature of gun politics, reciprocity in regard to weapons carry permits or licenses has been controversial.</p> <p>[39]^ Article IV, Section 1, &#8220;Full faith and credit shall be given in each state to the public acts, records, and judicial proceedings of every other state.&#8221;</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-13497">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-13497" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-13497"> http://www.facebook.com/tattoosbybill                <span id="dsq-author-user-13497">Bill Mckay</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-13497" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-13497" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Does anyone know if Pa and Va cancelled there resiprosity agreement</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-13508">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-13508" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-13508">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-13508">WOP 2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-13508" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-13508" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Bill:<br /> No, but the new Pennsylvania Attorney General, Kathleen Kane, is a shill for Bloomberg and for the Philadelphia anti gunners. First of all, Kathleen Kane, our new AG, has the right to enter into (and out of) reciprocity agreements. Why the legislature ever gave that to the AG&#8217;s office is beyond my comprehension. WE all knew she was anti-gun, but Soros, Bloomberg, and the Joyce Foundation poured a ton of money into her campaign, and of course the liberal dolts in Philly and Pittsburgh fell for it hook, line and sinker.<br /> Next step&#8211;for years, Lt. Lisa King, head of the License to Carry Firearms department in Philadelphia, along with Chief Ramsey and Deputy Commissioner Blackburn have routinely denied folks under Pennsylvania&#8217;s &#8220;character and reputation&#8221; clause. So, about 4000 folks spent the time, money (probably 150 bucks compared to 20 in PA), mandatory training (not required in PA) to obtain a Florida non-resident permit.<br /> Once the new administration got into power (the new AG) the Philadelphia coalition immediately clammored for her to kill the dreaded &#8220;Florida Loophole&#8221;. So, on her own, with no talking to the Legislature or the Governor, she came up with a rule that says&#8212;a Florida NON-RESIDENT permit is not recognized if the holder of the permit is a Pennsylvania resident, UNLESS said PA resident also has a PA License to Carry Firearms. So what do the 4000 do now? They have a short period of time to apply for a PA License to Carry Firearms.<br /> What you must know is that in the other 66 PA counties, the Sherrif issues the License. Philadelphia, our only city of the &#8220;First Class&#8221;, issues licenses through the Chief of Police&#8211;our anti gun ninny Ramsey. Truth be told, AG Kathleen Kane closed the Philadelphia loophole. The entire situation sucks, and PA House leadership is highly inflamed.<br /> Hope this qualifies as a &#8220;non-dumbass&#8221; remark <img src="http://www.usacarry.com/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_smile.gif" alt=":)" class="wp-smiley" /> Its long, but its accurate.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-13638">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-13638" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-13638">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-13638">Louis</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-13638" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-13638" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>They need to update the map Maryland will now reciprocate pa va de and wv ccw as of October of 2012  </p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-13656">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-13656" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-13656">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-13656">WOP 2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-13656" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-13656" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Really??? #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-14023">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14023" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14023">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14023">BBaker452</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14023" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div Florida allows tazer,mace,6&#8243;knife. Not Michigan. Do I gwt extra rights in Florida?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-14070">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14070" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14070">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14070">Sailingwindward</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14070" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14070" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>It doesn&#8217;t look good for &#8220;Concealed Carry&#8221; being recognized outside the home, at least on the federal level. Below are 3 cases leaning toward that the &#8220;Right to Keep and Bear Arms&#8221; does NOT extend outside the home.</p> <p>The Second U.S. Circuit Court upheld last November 27 New York State&#8217;s conceal carry law, which was very similar to Maryland&#8217;s in that it required a showing of &#8220;proper cause&#8221; to get a permit. The case was Kachalsky v. Westchester.</p> <p>The 10th U.S. Circuit Court ruled on February 22 in Peterson v. Martinez and shot down a challenge to the state conceal carry law, which limits permits to residents. In a sweeping ruling, the Court ruled that there is no Second Amendment right to carry a concealed firearm in public.</p> <p>The Fourth Circuit expressly avoided saying anything about the extent of the Second Amendment in the Wollard case, making the case unappealable to the U.S. Supreme Court. It simply ruled on March 21 that the state&#8217;s interest in protecting public safety and preventing crime justified the conceal carry permit law.</p> <p>So far the ONLY case were &#8220;Concealed Carry&#8221; was recognized outside the home is the Illinois case below:</p> <p>The Seventh U.S. Circuit ruled in Moore v. Madigan on December 11 that Illinois must enact a conceal carry permit law. It did so with a weak endorsement of the right to carry a loaded gun in public, saying that the Second Amendment &#8220;confers a right to bear arms for self-defense, which is as important outside the home as inside.&#8221;</p> <p>If the courts can&#8217;t agree on this, we ALL need to contact our congressional legislators to enact law that clarifies the right to keep and bear arms extends outside the home and in public places.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-14078">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14078" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14078">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14078">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14078" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14078" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You need to read a bit more. The REASON the 7th US Circuit court ruled the way it did is because of the ruling from the SCOTUS in the Heller case.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-14081">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14081" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14081">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14081">Sailingwindward</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14081" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14081" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I don&#8217;t read anywhere in the Heller decision were they ruled on concealed carry being a 2nd amendment right. Maybe, it&#8217;s a different Heller I&#8217;m looking at?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-14093">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14093" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14093">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14093">UYH</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14093" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14093" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>screw the entire North East when did they withdraw from the USA ?!..I thought they were still part of the USA, NO?Part of California ?Illinois?? I will never live somewhere that requires me to register my guns.</p> <p>&#8220;a class should be taken on safe use and more importantly how to handle a high stress situation with a firearm&#8221;</p> <p>While I agree that training is very helpful and useful, it should in no way be required to buy a firearm. We are talking about a RIGHT here, not a privilege.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-14432">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14432" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14432"> http://www.facebook.com/john.lee.1088893                <span id="dsq-author-user-14432">John Lee</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14432" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14432" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Concealed carry is not a 2nd Ammendment right. States grant their citizens permission to apply through laws legislators we elect pass. Be happy about this. We really don&#8217;t want others deciding for us. It is bad enough there are red/black states&#8230;glad I don&#8217;t live there.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-14450">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14450" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14450">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14450">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14450" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14450" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>&#8220;Concealed carry is not a 2nd Ammendment right. &#8221;</p> <p>Excuse me, but yes it is.</p> <p>&#8230;the RIGHT of the people to KEEP and BEAR arms shall not be infringed.</p> <p>RIGHT &#8211; If I have to explain this, there is no point.<br /> KEEP &#8211; This is what you do in your home. You have (keep) them.<br /> BEAR &#8211; This is what you do outside your home. You carry (bear) them.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-14434">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14434" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14434">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14434">cb69</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14434" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14434" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>how do you carry your weapon and ammo while traveling through states that do not allow concealed weapons permits ?<br /> Like Illinois ?</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-14449">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14449" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14449">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14449">WOP 2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14449" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14449" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Generally speaking, when transporting firearms THROUGH  a state in your travels, for example, Ilinois and Maryland, so long as your UNLOADED firearm is in a locked container, inaccessible to the driver and passengers, and your ammo is in a separate locked container,  you are good to go. Remember, if stopped for a traffic violations, many police officers are taught to go fishing. They&#8217;ll ask you if you mind if they take a look in your car. Your answer is always the same. &#8220;No thank you, officer, you DO NOT have my permission to search my car, my person, or any other occupants of this vehicle.&#8221; If they get pissy about it,  tell them you have all day long, and as soon as they produce a warrant, you&#8217;ll comply with it. I just got back from Chicago, and felt absolutely naked without my handgun. There were, I believe, 9 shootings on Friday and Saturday night.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-14488">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14488" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14488">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-14488">No</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14488" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14488" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Open carry is a right!!!! Similarly, if you are a New York resident keen to leave the State, the same rules apply. Just be cautious that the State you are traveling to doesn&#8217;t have some sort of draconian laws.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-14700">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-14700" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-14700"> http://www.facebook.com/dbrow6272                <span id="dsq-author-user-14700">Dan Brown</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-14700" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-14700" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Bob is correct. Simply lock your unloaded gun in a secure container not accessible to driver and passenger, and lock your ammo in a different container, also not easily accessible. Where you get your ass in a jam is if your final destination state has restrictions that are draconian, for example New Jersey or New York. It&#8217;s YOUR responsibility to know the laws on possession of a firearm, magazine capacity limits, and right to carry in the final destination state.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-15067">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-15067" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-15067">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-15067">anonymous2112</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-15067" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-15067" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Ohio and Nevada are a bunch of horses asses</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-15157">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-15157" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-15157"> http://www.facebook.com/anthony.guthrie2                <span id="dsq-author-user-15157">Anthony Guthrie</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-15157" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-15157" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Hey&#8230;I live in Nevada, and now ya got me wondering why you said that! Non residents are not required to have an Illinois FOID Card. It is recommended that in order to be in compliance with all statutes, non-residents transport all ﬁrearms:</p> <p>1. broken down in a non-functioning state; or<br /> 2. not immediately accessible; or<br /> 3. unloaded and enclosed in a case, ﬁrearm carrying box, shipping box, or other container</p> <p>This is directly from the Illinois State Police brochure. If you keep it locked in the glovebox, it will have to be &#8220;broken down in a non-functioning state&#8221;. Even though this is within the law, I would advise against it. You could run into someone unfamiliar with this.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-15547">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-15547" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-15547">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-15547">Jake from State Farm</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-15547" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-15547" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Wow&#8230; FUCK Illinois! Some states won&#8217;t require live fire, because of liability issues! For me, personally, training yes, absolutely, positively, and as much as I can get. MANDATORY training&#8211;never.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-16450">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16450" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16450">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16450">Diane Snow</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16450" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16450" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>good i&#8217;ll more than likely   try to get my permit here  then while i can before Barak hussien  obama   enacts the gun removal rights lol <img src="http://www.usacarry.com/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_razz.gif" alt=":P" class="wp-smiley" />  atleast i know what i&#8217;ll save for  when i have time to go to local gunstore and see if i can get a permit through them and then go from their &lt;3  if not im pretty much  very close to the  State police chief  any way     (mayor included <img src="http://www.usacarry.com/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_razz.gif" alt=":P" class="wp-smiley" /> )</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-16512">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16512" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16512">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16512">Larry Bishop</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16512" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16512" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>If you are required to get a permit to carry a gun then you should be required to get a permit to vote. It IS a protected right. See the 14th Amendment, but more specifically the 15th, and also recall that women were not allowed to vote until passage of the 19th Amendment. I don&#8217;t like to so stridently call you out on this, but you are very much ill informed on the RIGHT to vote.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-16519">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16519" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16519">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16519">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16519" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16519" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>The 26th Amendment, in my mind, is what really guarantees the right as it is referenced there similarly to the way rights are in the first 10 amendments.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-16742">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16742" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16742">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16742">Gregg</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16742" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16742" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>The Constitution, Article IV Sections and 2 compel ALL sates to accept my Indiana permit. Why has this not been challenged all the way to the SCOTUS?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-16864">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16864" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16864">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16864">Roundup_Logan</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16864" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16864" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I own a construction company and we travel the country all the time. It is an absolute nightmare to navigate across country and keep current on who accepts which license. I&#8217;m not sure it&#8217;s possible for a person to carry legally in all the lower 48 states being a resident in one state and traveling to all the others. So, does anyone know how a person can travel from the heartland (let&#8217;s say Kansas or Missouri) up to let&#8217;s say Connetticut or Maine without having to get 5 or 6 different permits? Is it even possible to obtain enough permits to be able to carry in all the lower 48 states? I currently have 3 different permits (1 resident and 2 non-resident) and still can&#8217;t traverse the continent with a loaded pistol. I&#8217;ve been subjected to fingerprinting, background checks, formal training, and have a squeeky clean background, yet I find myself an alien in my own country when it comes to self-defense and traveling by truck across the country. I&#8217;m totally against the federal government being involved, yet I find the state&#8217;s unwillingness to cooperate in reciprosity a complete nightmare. For instance, the fellow from New York who commented thinks that his state does it right and no other state&#8217;s permits should be honored in his state. ANYONE who&#8217;s issued a concealed carry permit in their state has gone through a background check, and has to be an upstanding citizen in his or her&#8217;s state to be issued the permit. Just because New York submits a 10-fingerprint card for an FBI background check doesn&#8217;t mean automatically their state has the best system. Both Kansas and Florida do the same thing &#8211; and guess what, New York doesn&#8217;t honor their permits. I find myself limiting travel through states which don&#8217;t honor the permits I hold. But back to my question: Can a person obtain enough permits so they can carry in all the states? Until that happens, we will remain divided on the topic.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-16868">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16868" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16868">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16868">JRS</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-16868" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-16868" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>So If have a permit to Conceal in the State of North Carolina driving to Wisconsin thru Illinois I have to separate and lock the firearm? Can I carry in Wisconsin or due to the Notes about Wisconsin I cannot carry?</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-16923">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-16923" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-16923">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-16923">W. Echols : NCCH Instructor</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17109" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17109" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>North Carolina now accepts all state permits if they issue one..</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-17112">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-17112" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-17112">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-17112">ozzy</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17112" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17112" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>States that have Home rule Charter laws allows cities to decide who can carry in each city/ county&#8230;. I used live in the state of Iowa, I was a Department of Transportation Enforcement Officer/ and also worked Private Security at the Same Time, I lived in Webster County Iowa, and had to Obtain My Professional Concealed Weapons Permit &amp; range Qualifications from their Office, When I applied I was Denied a Concealed Weapons permit / due to a personal beef the Sheriff had with My Grandfather.  My Bosses at the Iowa DOT and Private Security Company I was Working for had  me go  to the Polk County Sheriffs Office to apply and Qualify for my PROFESSIONAL PERMIT, Which I was  issued the permit and was allowed to carry.  Law Enforcement and Private security have stricter rules than REGULAR citizens when obtaining a Concealed carry permit, Law Enforcement &amp; private security has to go through classes the covers Deadly Force, Vicarious Liability, and pass a written test, and score above 80 % on the written, and then they have to qualify on the range Yearly with a Score of 70 % or better.  On the Back of every Law enforcements and Private securities Concealed Weapons Permit: It states ; Only allowed to carry while on Duty, Or in Uniform: so that is the Restriction Law Enforcement&amp; private Security has to abide by&#8230;. Citizens Get their Permits too easy&#8230;..</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-17117">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-17117" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-17117">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-17117">Confused User</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17117" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17117" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Confused by web page! It&#8217;s a privilege. I&#8217;m in NJ, but live 10 min from PA.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-17507">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-17507" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-17507">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-17507">rpyne</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17507" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17507" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>How about updating Idaho. Idaho now has two concealed permits. The enhanced permit is now recognized by Nevada.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-17624">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-17624" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-17624">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-17624">AvidShooter2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17624" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17624" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>do I have to be CONUS (in the country) to file for my CCW permit? im stationed in Germany and my leave ends soon. im wondering if I can file the paperwork and then return to my duty station while it is being processed. also for the state issued firearms classes: I am actve duty. does that take the place of the classes? if not, do I have to take a general firearms course or is there an advanced course for military personnel?</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-17643">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-17643" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-17643">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-17643">WOP 2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17643" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17643" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Depends on the State. You should be able to get an intelligent answer from the proper issuing authority. Some States consider military service as &#8220;training&#8221;, such as Florida. Others (Utah) do not, and some (Pennsylvania) have no training requirement at all.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-17694">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-17694" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-17694">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-17694">Mike</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17694" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17694" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>interesting&#8230; according to your map, my wisconsin permit is not honored in wisconsin</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-17713">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-17713" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-17713">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-17713">D.H.</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17713" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17713" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I live in Florida and possess a Florida CCW and will be visiting the Alexandria/Arlington Virginia area and I know that VA has reciprocity with FL but I don&#8217;t drive and generally depend on public transportation so I was wondering if I can carry a .9mm concealed on WMATA MetroBus or MetroRail? Other locals either honor my NC CCW, or they allow me to apply for a non-resident permit (such as Oregon, or Maine, etc).  I thought my constitutional right to bear arms  was a &#8220;national&#8221; right, not a right that was restricted based on where I happen to be standing at any particular point in time.  My free speech right doesn&#8217;t change from state to state; my right to a speedy trial doesn&#8217;t change from state to state; etc&#8230; So why is it that my right to bear arms changes from state to state?</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-17762">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-17762" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-17762">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-17762">Charles_Higley</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-17762" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-17762" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Do those states have open carry?</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-18467">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-18467" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-18467">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-18467">Joe6957</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-18467" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-18467" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I used to live in New Jersey. I am a doctor or pharmacist with access to drugs/&#8221;controlled substances&#8221;<br /> 3. similar &#8220;special status&#8221; individuals.<br /> When going to a shooting range, gun had to be unloaded and carried in car trunk. I assume that it is the latter, like trying to teach a pig to sing, so I seldom try.  Also, some of these rubes just like to get a rise out of those who believe differently than they do.  Still, I am glad that we are not all thinking alike.  But one point I wish to make is the American Psychiatric Association (or whatever its name) agrees that at least 1% of U.S. population is certifiably, violently insane, yet less than 900,000 are in asylums.  Now, our last census was what, 250 mill?  What&#8217;s wrong with that picture? The Fed. gov. made a &#8220;least restricted environment&#8221; law, which turned much of the population or asylums out.  The basic criteria were based on availability of drugs which could control their violence and their ability to function among &#8220;normal&#8221; people.  So, does it take a Ph.D to realize that when the drugs aren&#8217;t taken, the person turns violent again?  Evidently, or our stupid Congress would not have passed the law.  As for spelling, it is not a sign of intelligence, however it does show an ability to memorize, apply basic, although often incorrect rules, and exceptions to those rules.  It tends to make a person, at least from my perspective, look more educated and insures that understanding of your thoughts will be more likely.  I was a teacher who graduated when requirements were more strenuous than they have been since  1970.  I graded essays by grammar usage, spelling, punctuation, continuity of thought, and other basics of writing.  Now, anything that is considered mechanics is not emphasized in most schools.  In reviewing the requirements for an 8th grade certificate in the 1890&#8217;s, I realized that I may have had some difficulty as a graduate in 1966, although some of those difficulties would be due to a change in terminology, geopolitical changes, etc.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-18916">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-18916" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-18916">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-18916">Telemachus_1</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-18916" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-18916" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>what the hell does any of this have to do with anything on this website, let alone this page? They would love to see the worldwide return of a medieval type society where  a few were on the top and the rest supported them.  Don&#8217;t believe me?  Then, what does Lizzy do to help anyone?  Does she pay taxes, especially the inheritance tax which has hurt so many others?  No, on both counts.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-18711">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-18711" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-18711">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-18711">Laurence Almand</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-18711" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-18711" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Article IV of the Constitution states:  &#8220;Full faith and Credit shall be given in each State to the public Acts, Records, and judicial Proceedings of every other State.&#8221;   If a state must recognize the drivers&#8217; license of other states, it must also recognize the CCW license  &#8211; but tell that to New York and California.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-18745">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-18745" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-18745">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-18745">RockheadGT</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-18745" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-18745" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I am in the process of getting a suppressor. The paperwork and $200 check have been sent to the BATF&amp;E. Once I take possession of it I will no longer be able to move to several states, NY, Calif, etc. It&#8217;s like I won&#8217;t even be a citizen anymore. I have a total hearing loss in one ear from a cholestoma and some in the other due to submarine engine room noise. Using a suppressor will reduce the sound level by about 30 db, just about the same as a good pair of ear muffs. Tell me again why I shouldn&#8217;t have one.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-19657">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19657" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19657">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19657">GonzoI</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-19657" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-19657" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Because a congressman saw a scary bad guy in a spy film use one once. As a year rounder , most States will allow one to go thru the States with in 24 hours to where you are going to, as long as your fire arm is broken down in a locked box ! There are States that will allow you to only carry open and States that will allow you to carry hidden ! Before any of you wish to go any where in this Country, please call the Sherriff&#8217;s of each County and State you are going thru, to ask the laws where you are going thru first !
