OMG!  &#8230;jus kiddin.  thx for serving.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-19308">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19308" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19308">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19308">Kenworth</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-19308" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-19308" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I am a resident of Indiana – what bugs me is&#8230;  Indiana has a two tier process for issuing firearm permits&#8230; One locally and one on the state/federal level. I am an ex-police officer and field training officer with extensive firearms training, but I STILL had to go through the whole process of getting a firearms permit once I left the department (I was given no special treatment just because I was a police officer). The reason some states will not reciprocate is because they feel certain states do not meet what they feel to be an in-depth background check, or do not meet what they feel is their idea of quality firearms training. I can tell you, Indiana is just as in-depth as most states that do not reciprocate with us. I can&#8217;t use my permit in say &#8211; Ohio (who does not reciprocate with Indiana) – even though I’m an ex-police officer… I KNOW some people who live in Ohio that have permits – that – by my own experience, should NOT have an Ohio permit (or any state), but they do…  But MY experience and permit is NOT valid in Ohio.  My point is, there is no perfect way of determining who should or should not have a firearm permit, or what states should reciprocate with which other states.  My personal feelings are, if you have a clean background, and have attended at least a 10 hour firearm training course, certified through the state, you should be able to get a “National Firearm License”…  Meaning you should be able to carry your weapon to defend yourself and your family in ANY state in the United States!  If you have no criminal history, and have attended some firearm safety training, the right to self-preservation by whatever means, should not be dictated to us by ANY state or federal agency &#8211; Period!  Now before anyone gets all huffy and starts that ape-like bowing out of the chest about firearms training, let me just say, from MY experience as a police officer, MOST of the accidental gun related injuries or deaths I investigated over the years were due to inexperienced handlers, or an owner who left his/her weapon readily available to children or a home invader.  Most people may not need any form of training, but there are some who could use it&#8230;  How do you determine who has the experience necessary and who doesn&#8217;t?  Documented proof &#8211; that&#8217;s how.  If you attended any sort of safety course and have a certificate, you wouldn&#8217;t need to attend it again to get a permit.  OR, if you&#8217;re military, law enforcement or ex-law enforcement or military, you too should not have to attend a safety course again to get a permit&#8230;  I&#8217;ve NEVER seen a accidental firearm incident when the owner was properly trained.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-19311">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19311" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19311">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19311">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-19311" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-19311" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I&#8217;m not even sure where to start with this…so here we go.</p> <p>&#8220;Indiana has a two tier process for issuing firearm permits&#8230; One locally and one on the state/federal level.&#8221;</p> <p>No, they don&#8217;t. First, there is no &#8220;firearm permit&#8221; in Indiana. There is a &#8220;License to Carry a Handgun&#8221; which, from the topic of this page, is what I assume you&#8217;re talking about. Second, there is no tier system regarding the state and federal government. The federal government isn&#8217;t involved in the issuing of the licenses other than their criminal databases probably being used to check for a disqualifying criminal history.</p> <p>&#8220;I am an ex-police officer and field training officer with extensive firearms training, but I STILL had to go through the whole process of getting a firearms permit once I left the department (I was given no special treatment just because I was a police officer).&#8221;</p> <p>This sounds like you think you SHOULD be given special treatment just because you were a police officer. You shouldn&#8217;t; we don&#8217;t live in a class-based society. Also, you can get a nationwide permit/license through an HR218 ID card if you are retired law enforcement, so your point is moot.</p> <p>&#8220;I can tell you, Indiana is just as in-depth as most states that do not reciprocate with us.&#8221;</p> <p>The only thing that would comparable is the background check since Indiana has no training requirement. That is the main sticking point with other states that do have a training requirement. Even then, Indiana&#8217;s background check for the License isn&#8217;t as in depth as it once was and, as such, doesn&#8217;t even meet the requirements for bypassing a NICS check when purchasing a firearm.</p> <p>&#8220;My personal feelings are, if you have a clean background, and have attended at least a 10 hour firearm training course, certified through the state, you should be able to get a “National Firearm License”… Meaning you should be able to carry your weapon to defend yourself and your family in ANY state in the United States!&#8221;</p> <p>Well, your personal feelings are ridiculous. The license/permit at the national level is the 2nd Amendment; that&#8217;s all that should be needed. You don&#8217;t have to get a permit or license to exercise any other rights and certainly not any of the others in the Bill Of Rights.</p> <p>&#8220;How do you determine who has the experience necessary and who doesn&#8217;t? Documented proof &#8211; that&#8217;s how.&#8221;</p> <p>Yes, documented proof that you are in the US legally. Again, that is all that should be needed.</p> <p>&#8220;OR, if you&#8217;re military, law enforcement or ex-law enforcement or military, you too should not have to attend a safety course again to get a permit&#8230; I&#8217;ve NEVER seen a accidental firearm incident when the owner was properly trained.&#8221;</p> <p>Again, you&#8217;re trying to create a separate class of people and trying to benefit yourself in the process. Police, and specifically in Indiana since I&#8217;m familiar with the state&#8217;s requirements, aren&#8217;t trained nearly to the level they should be and the vast majority are far below individual citizens that have chosen to get training. And, if you haven&#8217;t seen an accidental discharge from somebody that was &#8220;properly trained&#8221;, then you haven&#8217;t been around firearms for very long. It happens even to the best.</p> <p>Training is great for those who have the opportunity, myself included since I have, but it most certainly should not be a requirement to exercise a right. Even though I&#8217;ve had the training, I will fight against anyone who says somebody shouldn&#8217;t have the right, regardless of my personal feeling about that particular person.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-19350">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19350" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19350">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19350">CrazyHungarian</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-19350" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-19350" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>What is the best combination of non-resident CCW State licenses to have? That is if you like to travel a lot.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-19351">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19351" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19351">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19351">WOP 2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-19351" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-19351" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I&#8217;d start with Utah, one that I am familiar with, and work from there. Note-if you a Pennsylvania resident, our Attorney General, has already killed recognition of most non resident licenses, including Florida and Virginia, for PA residents. Let me be clear as a bell on this, or I&#8217;ll get scorched by some folks who understand how this all works. I AM a PA resident. Therefore, according to the most recent PA Superior Court challenges, any non resident permits or licenses from other States are NOT recognized in Pennsylvania. My Utah permit IS recognized outside of PA in all of the States shown on the map for non resident reciprocity. To carry here in Pennsylvania, I MUST have a Pennsylvania License to Carry Firearms. (yes, I do have one.)</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-19352">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19352" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19352">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19352">CrazyHungarian</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-19352" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-19352" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Thanks. Idaho now has TWO different permits, the Basic CCW and the Enhanced CCW. The Enhanced CCW is accepted in Virginia, South Carolina, New Mexico, and Nevada. West Virginia also changed some statutes this past year that now causes the state to accept Idaho&#8217;s Basic CCW.  Idaho&#8217;s new permit was inaugurated back in September. And also, Washington State is considering reciprocity between our two states. That&#8217;d be a great state of affairs for us all!</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-19886">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19886" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19886">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19886">Robert K. If you have reciprocity in Indiana, you can carry. Ilinois has no provision just yet for carry. You may, however, use Federal safe passage laws in Ilinois by locking your gun in container, not accessible to driver or passenger, and placing your ammo in a similar locked container. Its up to YOU to make absolutely certain that YOU know the laws in each State you travel through. No 2 States are exactly alike.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-19892">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-19892" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-19892">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-19892">Glen Moorehead</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-19892" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-19892" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Does Michigan issue a non-resident permit?<br /> Answer: NO They only issue to Res.! &#8211; What?</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-20018">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20018" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20018">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20018">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20018" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20018" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>No, Illinois allows you to TRANSPORT a firearm in a vehicle under those rules, not carry on your person in a vehicle.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-20042">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20042" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20042">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20042">Doug Belt</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20042" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20042" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>&#8220;Illinois allows residents of other states carry a concealed firearm in their vehicle&#8230;&#8221;  this says residents of other states who hold a concealed carry permit from their own state, may carry a concealed weapon as long as they do not leave their vehicle while carrying said weapon concealed.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-20046">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20046" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20046">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20046">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20046" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20046" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>If that is true, it is a change from what was originally published. I would have to see an official publication from the state of Illinois to believe it.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-20047">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20047" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20047">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20047">Doug Belt</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20047" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20047" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You somehow misinstalled the word &#8220;transport&#8221; into your misinterpretation of the law. Read the wording of the law as it is written, with no wording imposed by you.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-20048">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20048" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20048">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20048">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20048" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20048" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>No, I was using the initial statements made by Illinois, that they would not recognize carry permits from other states, in combination with the GOPA of 1986 that says you can transport firearms through states even if you don&#8217;t have a carry permit there.</p> <p>I didn&#8217;t misinterpret anything; I just hadn&#8217;t, and still haven&#8217;t, seen any statement(s) by Illinois that changed that.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-20239">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20239" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20239">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20239">ihavetopickastupidname</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20239" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20239" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>My comment above was pulled straight from this website.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-20032">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20032" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20032">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20032">Robin Sterling</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20032" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20032" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>The thought that we are one country is where this country gets itself into trouble. We are 50 sovereign states that agree to be bound by a central government and constitution.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-20183">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20183" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20183">                 <span Not an argument I would want to have to litigate on my own dime or time, but it should be unbeatable, given that the 2nd A is much stronger than the vague extension of the 14th A to gay marriage.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-20795">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20795" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20795">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20795">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20795" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20795" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>There is nothing vague about either right.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-20801">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20801" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20801">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20801">Dayallaxeded</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20801" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20801" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Please keep saying that.  Loudly, often, and especially to authoritarians of every stripe.  I don&#8217;t agree with your opinion about the relative clarity of the 14th A, but if that&#8217;s what it takes to get people to recognize that the 2nd A, likewise and even moreso, constitutes a fundamental and inalienable right of citizens that the states are not empowered to abridge, well thanks for your efforts.  In this we are allies.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-20806">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20806" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20806">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20806">Laurence Almand</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20806" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20806" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I think Virginia&#8217;s ban has been struck down.  Who cares who people are married to?  That&#8217;s a private matter.  The  2nd Amendment, however, is NOT a private matter &#8211; it is of upmost public concern.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-20842">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20842" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20842">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20842">Dayallaxeded</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20842" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20842" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You seem to have missed my point&#8211;the federal courts are saying states, like Virginia (yes it&#8217;s the one most recently slapped by the feds) can&#8217;t regulate marriage differently from the most liberal (on marriage laws) state out there&#8211;they must permit or at least honor marriages, including SSM or whatever is permitted in the most liberal (on marriage laws) states.  If you&#8217;re married in Vermont, you&#8217;re married in Virginia, Kentucky, and maybe in every state (once SCOTUS rules on this), no matter what laws or constitutional provisions exist in those other states.  Substitute &#8220;CCWs&#8221; for &#8220;marriages&#8221; in the above.  I hope it gets rammed down NJ&#8217;s and NY&#8217;s throats.  This is all very much of public concern.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-20995">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20995" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20995">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20995">Jeff O&#8217;</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20995" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20995" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Dayall, it&#8217;s all right here in the full faith &amp; credit clause: Art. IV, Sec. 1.  It reads as follows:</p> <p>“Full Faith and Credit shall be given in each State to the public Acts, Records, and judicial Proceedings of every other State. And the Congress may by general Laws prescribe the Manner in which such Acts, Records and Proceedings shall be proved, and the Effect thereof.”</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-21022">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-21022" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-21022">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-21022">Dayallaxeded</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-21022" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-21022" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>um, no.  see, BAKER et al. v. GENERAL MOTORS CORP., 522 U.S. 222 (1998) etc.  States still have and should have maximum sovereign autonomy to legislate on all matters not expressly delegated to the feds (a tiny set of powers that have been inflated beyond all recognition&#8211;aka, fubar) or expressly reserved as fundamental rights to the people (like the subjects of the Bill of Rights).  States have long had different marriage laws.  People can marry at different ages, to different degrees of consanquinity (i.e., cousins), and with different requirements for dissolution in different states.  It&#8217;s a much richer (or tackier, depending on how you look at it) tapestry than the LGBT squeaky wheels want you to consider.  My point is how beautifully ironic that the same social/political cadres that routinely rail against the 2nd A as an inviolate individual right are going to get hoisted on their own pitard, because the same arguments they&#8217;re ramming down everyone&#8217;s throats by force should and will be used to ram real rights, like the 2nd A down everyone&#8217;s throats, too.  It&#8217;s not the right way to do it, but if it can start a trend back to recognition of truly equal, individual rights and responsibilities, I&#8217;m glad of it.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-20948">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20948" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20948">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20948">V Tramell</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20948" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20948" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>A judge did rule it unconstitutional, but stayed the ruling knowing it would be appealed. So the law is still in effect.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-20846">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-20846" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-20846">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-20846">Chris</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-20846" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-20846" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Colorado Sucks, How does one exercise their 2nd Amendment Rights if They will not issue a Non-Resident a CCW? Mainly because the rest don&#8217;t want to bother with it.<br /> Try Coulmbia county (west of Portland), St. Helens is where you want to go to get the permit. The Sheriff there used to be great about issuing CCW&#8217;s to people from Washington. Hopefully that hasn&#8217;t changed since I moved away.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-21432">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-21432" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-21432">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-21432">Ex Californian &#8211; Virginia now</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-21432" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-21432" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Why not treat a gun the same as a car?  Pay a fee for the privilege to carry.  Register the gun &#8211; yearly.  Renew the carry permit every two years.  Background checks, competency, safe use and judgment testing too.   Your carry permit is for a specific gun.  Want to carry different types?  Permit for each type &#8211; tied to the S/N of the weapon you are carrying.  Caught with a gun that is not registered or tied to the correct carry permit, pay fine.  Sounds like the government right?  Well, two things are for sure:  1).  You will  NEVER  get rid of the guns that are out there.  2).  You will  NEVER  have all the sates work in conjunction unless it falls under a federal rule or guideline.   Basically you pay if you want to play.  Too poor to cover the nut?  How much did you pay for the gun?  If you can own gun(s) and buy ammo you can afford to pay for the right to carry CCW.   The lines for &amp; against guns are so divided it will never be decided unless proper legislation happens.  Oh, as for the money &#8211; put it into the background system used to check.  Beef it up.  With the number of guns (legal) out there, probably will be a surplus.  Maybe create additional or national violent crime victims funds, better training for handgun use and safety.   Heck, maybe also snatch a few bucks to put to the deficit?  But sitting back and pointing fingers and complaining will not solve anything.  Come up with a revenue generating idea and I&#8217;m sure politicians will salivate over &#8220;Mo Money, Mo Money, MO MONEY!!!&#8221;   But that&#8217;s just my opinion, i could be wrong&#8230;.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-21444">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-21444" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-21444">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-21444">TUCO-the-ratt</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-21444" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-21444" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>You are wrong.<br /> Are you Dianne Feinstein lurking under a pseudonym?</p> <p>States will never agree exactly about concealed carry. That&#8217;s OK, they&#8217;re not supposed to. That&#8217;s why it&#8217;s called the United States of America instead of the State of America. Don&#8217;t forget it&#8217;s called the Bill of RIGHTS not the the Bill of Privileges. I suggest you move back to California register everything you have and study American History for a while before posting again.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-21741">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-21741" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-21741">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-21741">Frank Castle</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-21741" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-21741" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>This is the reason that Virginia has to worry and I live in Virginia. Or will be offered weekly as soon as the instructors are certified, or some other such nonsense.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-22819">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22819" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22819">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22819">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22819" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22819" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>This is NOT a states&#8217; rights issue. But you&#8217;re right, they would mess it all up.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-23020">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23020" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23020">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23020">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23020" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23020" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>He doesn&#8217;t have a point on anything except you wouldn&#8217;t want a federal permit. This isn&#8217;t a states&#8217; rights issue. It is simply forcing the states to respect, and obey, the US Constitution. They all agreed to do so.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-23032">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23032" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23032">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23032">Guilford King</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23032" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23032" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I would just like the right to carry my gun with me legally in any state. That right does not exist now. A law abiding citizen with no police record should not be punished for having a weapon. Any veteran with arms training should not have to take a course on how to shoot a gun. Indiana doesn&#8217;t require that, but Ohio does and won&#8217;t recognize an Indiana permit. It&#8217;s all about money.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-22416">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22416" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22416">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22416">BGW</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22416" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22416" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Screw<br /> Permit(s) Not Honored In:</p> <p>California, Connecticut, Guam, Hawaii, Illinois, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Nevada, New Jersey, New York, New York City, Oregon, Puerto Rico, Rhode Island, Virgin Islands, Wisconsin, American Samoa, District of Columbia, N. The only one it doesn&#8217;t recognize is New York City&#8217;s because the city isn&#8217;t a state.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-22907">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22907" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22907">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22907">garyamusic .</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22907" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22907" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>The tax code is easier to understand than this reciprocity bs!</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-22909">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22909" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22909">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22909">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22909" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22909" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I&#8217;m not sure why it&#8217;s so hard to understand. Either a state recognizes your permit or they don&#8217;t. It isn&#8217;t complicated.</p> <p>Also, for you and everyone else here that keeps using the term reciprocity. This map does not show reciprocity; it shows what states recognize another state&#8217;s permit one at a time. Reciprocity is when two states recognize each others permits respectively, not just one or the other.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-22911">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22911" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22911">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22911">garyamusic .</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22911" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22911" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Perhaps I should have been a little more clear in my statement and then asked a few questions.  Why don&#8217;t we have a simple Federally approved nationwide CCW? Why isn&#8217;t my home state&#8217;s license (ca) recognized in every other state in the union?  It&#8217;s probably tougher to get one here than anywhere!  Why is it that Idaho recognizes everyone&#8217;s CCW (except Vermont) but everyone does not recognize Idaho&#8217;s?  Why is it that some states only recognize a permit issued to a person if that&#8217;s their home state but not one that&#8217;s issued to them by another state?  And so on and so on&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;&#8230;</p> <p>It get&#8217;s to be quite complicated when one travels as much as I do.  Not to mention the constant changes in these silly laws, a background check is just that right!  I mean with these things called computers and all surely they can keep tabs on a guy/gal regardless of which state he&#8217;s in should he break some law that would disqualify him.  Heck, my credit card company can keep track of me all over the globe!  </p> <p>I think most of us know what reciprocity means (you do me and I&#8217;ll do you) but thanks for the lesson anyhow.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-22953">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22953" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22953">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22953">XDs</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22953" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22953" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Does anyone know why Georgia does not recognize SC or VA (and vice versa)? It just doesn&#8217;t make sense. I know it&#8217;s a wide open question, but would appreciate any input from someone &#8220;in the know&#8221;. Thanks!</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-23356">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23356" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23356">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23356">G8R8U2</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23356" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23356" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Because neither of those states will honor Georgia&#8217;s. In the case of South Carolina, they require classes and tests to acquire a CCW, and Georgia does not require anything other than being legal and paying the fee. </p> <p>South Carolina considers that inadequate to own and carry a weapon, so they don&#8217;t honor Georgia&#8217;s permits. Therefore Georgia will not honor theirs.</p> <p>I don&#8217;t know for certain about Virginia, but I suspect there&#8217;s a similar problem. Seems some states don&#8217;t want Americans from other states carrying guns in their states if they haven&#8217;t either passed their (S.C.) state&#8217;s requirements or passed similar requirements in their own state.</p> <p>Quite a few of us take our tourism dollars elsewhere for this very reason; you can&#8217;t expect people to travel around the country without the ability to protect themselves and their families, so many of us only vacation in states that honor our permits.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-22984">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22984" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22984">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22984">smith and wesson fans</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22984" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22984" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>My wife is going on a trip to see family in North Carolina traveling from Michigan thru OH, WV she is a ccw  holder she is going to take her pistol ( registered in her name ) and she wanted to take one of mine ( registered in my name ) so she can go shooting with her dad &#8230;. Question  &#8230;.. if she did get pulled over for any reason would she have any problem having my gun that&#8217;s not registered to her</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-22986">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22986" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22986">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22986">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22986" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22986" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Outside of Michigan, their registration law has no bearing on whether you can have the firearm or not. There is no federal registration so the other states would probably just make sure you are following their laws.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-22994">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-22994" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-22994">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-22994">knight10</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-22994" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-22994" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I see alot of bitching and complaining about being able to carry in various states and alot of people are against it. First there should not be concealed carry permits. That is what the Second Amendment is for. Do we have to get a permit to speak or think? No Constitutional Right should require a permit.</p> <p>I live in Ohio, two miles from the Pennsylvania border. We do not reciprocate. Pennsylvania is a shall issue State, even to out of State residents. The problem is, the local Sheriffs decide if they will do the paper work. Last time I checked, they won&#8217;t.</p> <p>So now, if I need to go somewhere that takes me into PA, I have to leave my gun at home. If I stay in Ohio, I&#8217;m fine. It makes no sense at all.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-23002">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23002" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23002">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23002">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23002" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23002" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>If they are shall issue, the sheriffs do not have that discretion. That&#8217;s what &#8220;shall issue&#8221; means. If they are choosing not to, they are breaking the law. Report/sue them.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" Any thoughts?<br /> Ernie</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-23463">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23463" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23463"> http://webbpage.cwahi.net/                <span id="dsq-author-user-23463">RadarRecon</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23463" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23463" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>States still have some rights that have not been taken away by D.C.</p> <p>BTW, the right to secede is also included in the 10th Amendment (though not mentioned specifically).</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-23464">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23464" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23464">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23464">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23464" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23464" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>The 10th Amendment does not give states the right to secede. There is no right to secede in the United States, short of revolution.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-23465">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23465" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23465"> http://webbpage.cwahi.net/                <span id="dsq-author-user-23465">RadarRecon</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23465" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23465" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Have you actually READ the 10th Amendment?  Maybe a refresher is in order.<br /> &#8220;The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor<br /> prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively,<br />  or to the people.&#8221;</p> <p>The &#8220;united&#8221; &#8220;states&#8221; joined together voluntarily to form a union, not forced to (the unlawful &#8220;Civil War&#8221; notwithstanding).  Having been voluntary, they can also separate themselves voluntarily because they are not &#8220;prohibited by&#8221; the Constitution from doing so.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-23468">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23468" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23468">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23468">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23468" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23468" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>&#8220;Having been voluntary, they can also separate themselves voluntarily because they are not &#8220;prohibited by&#8221; the Constitution from doing so.&#8221;</p> <p>Wrong. The union of the states is a permanent one. This has been ruled on by the Supreme Court. There is no legal way for a state to remove itself from said union, short of rebellion or, the only other option, the other states allowing it.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="dsq-comment-23611">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23611" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23611">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23611">Rich White</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23611" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23611" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Article 1 Section 10 of the United State Constitution states, &#8220;No State shall enter into any Treaty, Alliance, or Confederation&#8230;&#8221;  Now where does the right to secede come from?  The Constitution clearly states that what the south did was unconstitutional and illegal.  While states joined voluntarily, once they signed and ratified the Constitution they were contractually bound to honor and obey it.  Seceding and entering into the Confederacy was not permitted under the Constitution as spelled out in the above article.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-23613">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23613" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23613">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23613">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23613" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23613" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Completely correct, Rich.</p> <p>There are actually only two ways a state can leave the union. One is what was attempted during the civil war, armed revolution. The other is if the other states vote to allow it, and even then there is no defined way for that to happen. It would be a &#8220;try it and see what happens&#8221; kind of thing.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-23493">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-23493" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-23493">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-23493">Dave</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-23493" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-23493" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I think anyone who served in the military should be able to carry in any state in the country. That said, open carry and concealed carry are not mutually exclusive and, generally speaking, a location that allows open carry will have concealed carry as well. I&#8217;ve never heard of a state switching to exclusively open carry and getting rid of concealed carry. They generally just add one or the other, whichever they are missing.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-24073">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-24073" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-24073">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-24073">flyr</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-24073" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-24073" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Classifying California as a May Issue state is a joke for a majority of the residents in Los Angeles , San Francisco, Alameda , and Santa Barbara</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-24088">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-24088" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-24088">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-24088">Mike Golden</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-24088" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-24088" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>That confusing bunch of reciprocity laws will soon come to and end when the Republicans pass a national reciprocity law when they take over. It will no doubt be vetoed by the president however the pressure will be on the entire congress to override the veto. And I would think some Democrats would vote for it as will.</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-24089">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-24089" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-24089">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-24089">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-24089" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-24089" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>This is not the way to approach this. We must get the Supreme Court to rule on it. The 2nd Amendment in itself guarantees the right to carry.</p> </div>         </div>     </li><!-- #comment-## --> </ul><!-- .children --> </li><!-- #comment-## -->     <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-24237">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-24237" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-24237">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-24237">Jacob Hughes</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-24237" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-24237" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>Hate to whine but&#8230; why in the F does my state of Alabama allow most all states but&#8230; only a few accept Alabama&#8217;s? You guys still pissed about the war? LOL</p> </div>         </div>     <ul class="children">     <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-24238">         <div id="dsq-comment-header-24238" class="dsq-comment-header">             <cite id="dsq-cite-24238">                 <span id="dsq-author-user-24238">cawpin</span>             </cite>         </div>         <div id="dsq-comment-body-24238" class="dsq-comment-body">             <div id="dsq-comment-message-24238" class="dsq-comment-message"><p>I&#8217;m guessing Alabama doesn&#8217;t require a training class for a carry license/permit.
